reviewText:
If you are interested in Real pinball, as in machines out in the real world. This is the game for you.
All the tables are based on real tables, and does a pretty good job of it. So after playing the tables in this game, you already know what to shoot for out in the real world, and your scores will be that much greater.
However, Make sure you run this game in DX11, and make sure you adjust the lighting. (I usually go for 10-15% room brightness and 90-100% lamp brightness, to better emulate how games typically will look like in the real world.)


Now for the bad parts. (Why you shouldn't buy this game)

DX11
Most people will not know how to run this game in DX11, so the game will look like crap tbh. And when you see the same machine in the real world, it will not look familiar at first. (because in RL it will be much darker.) in short, this game will not look like the screenshots to most people. (I'm sure this issue will eventually be addressed.)

Pricing
My biggest complaint here is that you have to pay extra to get access to Pro-menus"
This means you can't tweak the tables to match Tournament settings
date: where extra balls are usually turned off. This is the biggest complaint I have about that. Some might argue
recommended:
but I feel this is just a moneygrab.

FPS
The game is locked at max 60fps. As someone who has been used to playing at 120fps on another game

reviewText:
As pinball goes the game play is terrific and Pinball Arcade has been absent from Steam for far too long.  The fact that it had to go through Greenlight is more testament to Valve's incompetence and lack of understanding of the genre.

Farsight includes a free table with the distribution of their platform.  Tales of Arabian Nights is outrageously good.  Personally I can sit in one spot from dusk until dawn ignoring hunger or nature calling playing this table.  The music, sound and game-play are all top notch.  Unfortunately the pot ain't all roses and there are some weeds, hopefully not permanently.

Graphically the package is a disappointment.  I don't know much about the studio but there are many aspects of the package that are missing or not up to par and diminish what should be one the premier titles on the steam store.

The game has shipped with post-processing bug so you must turn off this feature (some tables)  which denigrates the graphical presentation even further.  Still, when it works post-processing is no more than a gimmick to cover up the textural inadequacies of the tables.

The distribution model of the tables created quite a stir when Pinball Arcade made it's Steam debut.  Table packages were treated as IAPs or in app purchases and not as Steam recognized downloadable content.  Problems with this model included the inability to send Steam gifts or the guarantee that tables would be available if Farsight ever went under though I'm unsure exactly where IAP content is hosted.  The claim for the model was said to be based on that there were too many table packages in too many configurations, normal" vs "pro"  (more on that will follow)
hoursPlayed: custom ball packs.   Farsight responded and negotiated a compromise with Valve where the "normal" and "pro" season packs would be published as official Steam downloadable content and each would have it's own product page.  Personally I'm waiting for this to happen before buying any tables.  The rest would remain as IAPs
voteText: still a concern.\n\nThe "normal" and "pro" packages just seem unnecessary and unwarranted.  Do people who buy the "normal" tables not want the ability to scan the tables or occasionally fiddle with the menu?  Sure
helpfulPercent: I understand that such features are not absolute must haves but the classification of the packages without these features as "normal" is misguided and has been mishandled.  Lacking such features in a pinball package is not "normal" and paying up to 75% more for them is wrong and further
votesHelpful: should not be marketed to me as "pro".  It's a joke and an insult to fans of the studio.\n\nUsually I'm all in for this genre.  I would of gladly purchased all of their content day one but their incompetent marketing has left a bad taste.  I will own all of the "pro" tables but I'm not paying a mark-up for a faux "pro" marketing technique meant to take advantage of the naive consumer.  I would of bought the package at the "pro" unit price if there was no such demarcation between "normal and "pro" but I'll wait for the "pro" season discount.  If that never comes then so be it.  It's principle and besides

In many aspects ZEN's product presentation is vastly superior.  The question is can Farsight deliver more than their excellent engine.  Can they improve the presentation

not lump us in with phone and tablet users.

Get your act together Farsight.  Your product does not cast a positive light on your studio.  We expect a polished product.  Pinball Arcade is not that polished product though the pinball is stupendous.

reviewText:
Decided to do a revision of the old.

Definitely one of the closest games to the real thing, alongside the upcoming Pro Pinball ULTRA Editions.
The tables within may seem pricey at first, but when you consider replay value, it's totally worth paying for the Season Packs. Whether to get the Pro version is up to you, though, so choose wisely.

REVISION ADD: This game has helped me become close to mastery; pinball on Steam is basically the only thing I have where I live. There aren't very many machines around me, so this game, among others (although not perfect in gameplay), and alongside PAPA's tutorials, really help me bring my skill level up to a point where I can play competitively. reviewText:
Tables are WAY too expensive. 'Pro packs' are a ripoff; operator menus should just be included.

Not to mention that if you play this game on any other platforms you are required to repurchase tables for no good reason. The data for the tables is obviously the same between platforms.

Farsight has a login for scores, and could sync your purchased tables for use across multiple platforms/devices. But they don't, because then you'd only ever have to pay once.

Farsight is a greedy developer, do not support them.

reviewText: I LOVE to play pinball arcade. Very fun! It has a much different feel than Pinball FX 2, if you own that,  the flipper and ball action will feel much different. More of a feel of a real pinball machine. It took me a few weeks to get totally used to it and now the differences don't bother me. So if you do purchase the game give it some time to get the feel for it and th adjustment will happen. The graphics and sound are good, most of the tables I have (I have pack one only) feel just like they did when I played the real thing years ago. I enjoy nearly all the tables in pack one except for 3 or 4 of them. My personal favorite, Attack from Mars, is awesome, I feel like I'm back at my old arcade hangout, putting ten bucks of quarters in to the machine LOL. If you love pinball or are just getting into it I highly recommend Pinball Arcade pack one.

reviewText:
Decided to give this game a shot, due to the current summer sale deal (3 tables for $0.01)

From what I've been seeing, this game is more of a sim, than other pinball games, Off the bat, the ball physics felt a tad off to me. The ball felt a little light. Maybe I just got use to the physics of the FX2 ball, but regardless, I still enjoyed the game. I've played other pinball games where the ball just doesn't feel right at all, and it ruins the entire game.

I grew up during the arcade era. I immediately recognized a ton of tables I would see and wanted to play, but didn't due to me being so bad at pinabll, that i'd just end up wasting the $1 my dad would give me and just play for like 5 mins. He was good at pinball, he would constantly earn free games that he would let me have after he was done with his original credit.

There's not much to say really. If you like pinbal, this game is worth a shot. It's really nice how they recreated real tables. It's hard for people not to compare this game with FX2. They're both good pinball games that offer something different. FX offering stuff that could never be produced in a real table, like beaming down your ball in a light saber. I personally like that, but could also go for a bit more realistic experience. This definitely makes you feel like you have one of those giant pinball machines in your home.

reviewText:
Perhaps this is a review. It is what it is.

As a small child I spent much of my time at the beach resorts of Myrtle Beach & Surfside Beach, both (then) small towns in South Carolina, USA. Their beachfront pavillions were filled with 10-cent wonders at a time when children of any age could wander freely, alone. I remember the feeling of a pocket full of parent's pennies, waiting to to be magically converted to dimes for 4-in-a-strip sepia photos, flattened friendship tokens, skeeball to be turned into tickets (never really understanding why banked shots worked best), shooting galleries with actual pellets, and most magical of all, pinball. And spending those dimes with the feeling of a slight sunburn in a time when we still had ozone, but didn't yet have sunscreen. And going home when the pennies, and most of the magic, were gone, fingertips smelling like stale tobacco, having spent the last dimes on snowcones.

A week ago these memories were undescribable, and quit vague. Then I acquired Pinball Arcade, and all these memories became so very, very real. And memories about becoming a teenager, meeting girls (or wishing to), learning to drive, going to the prom. Going to bars for the first time, usually alone. But even when alone, pinball was there to comfort me when I was unable to talk to girls. Pinball as a way to meet other guys like me that may have never been my friends otherwise. Yes, these VERY tables, over several decades.

So I thank Pinball Arcade for reminding me of the pain, and the absolute joy, of childhood, adolesence, and growing into adulthood in a way that nothing else on Earth could have reminded me. Thank you for the pinball, and for allowing me to express myself in this pseudo-review.

reviewText:
Don't mind my hours because I've played a ton of Pinball Arcade. I first fell in love with it on the Playstation 3 and eventually moved to the Steam version, which I like much more. I highly recommend getting the season packages. In fact, this is put out by a fairly small outfit with a lot of dedication and passion for pinball, so I pay extra for the pro pack to help support them. I don't even mess with the extra stuff that comes with the pro, except maybe ball skins. They're just worth it.

If you don't know, buying a past season gives you all the games from that season, since they've already released. Your game (Pinball Arcade) updates a few minutes after your purchase, so there isn't an install, unless things have changed since I bought one last. If you buy the current season, there may only be a few games but be patient. Similar to a current season of TV episodes, the games are still being released and you'll get them as they come until the purchased season is over. It gives you something to look forward to!

As an 80s kid, I didn't have money for plunking into pinball or arcade machines. I was one of those who would stand around and watch others play, just to feel the excitement. My father worked in a factory and would sometimes bring home an actual pinball that popped out of a big machine on occasion. I settled for rolling that around on the floor (sad, I know!)

But now, I have more than I could ever dream at my fingertips! And they're so realistic! Farsight takes the actual tables and dissects them, ensuring we get as authentic an experience as possible besides playing the real thing. And while owning real pinball machines sounds great, think of the upkeep and expense, not to mention the room you'd need. It's a romantic thought, but this is way better.

I have a number of pinball video games, but there are two that rule supreme for me: Pinball FX2 (Zen) and Pinball Arcade. I love Zen Pinball for the fantasy angle. They make excellent tables that never existed so anything is possible, especially with Marvel and Star Wars! But when I want to play something that was actually crafted and made the rounds back when I was wishing I could play, that's when Pinball Arcade comes through for me.

I play using a Logitech Gamepad F310, by the way, and it works great!

This is my first time actually sitting down and writing a review here (I think), so I hope it was worth a poop.

reviewText:
When I first started to play Pinball Arcade, I felt it was sub-standard to Pinball FX.  However, as I  got to play more of the tables from all of the initial seasons 1,2 and 3, I found many of the tables were brilliant and played almost like the real thing.  I can actually remember a couple of the tables  contained within this series from my days as a student.  There's a wide variety of table types and apart from a couple that I found difficult to  keep the pinballs in play, most were  a pleasure to play.  The graphics may be slightly  rougher than Pinball FX, but I think that's because the developer has tried to capture the original feel of the tables rather than create totally  new digital only tables[ it works.

I have found the  high score achievements  in the main were very easy to acquire.  As for pledging money towards  development of more tables for future  seasons. if you buy the seasons on Steam, you pay for all future  tables that are to be added to that season, so beware when backing the tables via Kickstarter.    I've backed  four or five tables via Kickstarter, not realizing they were part of the same Pinball Arcade set as the Steam version, which I purchased earlier this year when they were released,  so I've wasted a good $100 which could have been spent buying at least a couple of the Pro season packs.

I mentioned this to the  developers, who have been really good about it and  offered extra's, or the option to gift  the tables I've backed that i already purchased via Steam.

One positive that the FX tables have over the arcade version is that you can buy  most of the tables seperately, which means you can build up your collection slowly; very useful if you are strapped for cash.  That said, overall  I think the season packs that   you get for the Pinball  Arcade version are much better value for money.


Once all of season 4's tables are added there will be over 50 tables to play.  The first of season 4 has already been added, i.e.  'Phantom of the Opera', the last of Season three was added recently i.e.  'Bram Stokers Dracula'.   Don't   be scared off by the price of these  season packs, when you consider how many tqables are contained within each pack you'll realise  that they  are excellent value for money; moreso if you buy them in a sale later this year.  Season 4 will probably be excluded from the sales,  at least until it's got it's full complement of tables, (10 in all).  The main difference between the  season packs and the Pro packs is that you get  lots of extra's such as  selectable balls, backgrounds etc.  You may be able to purchase these balls as packs via the basic version of the game, but i can't say for certain as I purchased the Pro versions.  I did have to buy one of the ball packs, but it was  dirt cheap (£0.69).

reviewText:
Players not used to pinball in general may find Pinball Arcade somewhat frustrating at first. It's just one of those things you have to persevere with. If you do, you will be rewarded with an experience that hones your instincts like a sport. There is strategy to it, patience, luck, and the need for twitch reflexes. Basically, everything's a target and you are constantly scoring points and bonuses, so it has a highly addictive effect on the reward system of your brain.

A great deal of production time was invested in making the original pinball machines, and that finds its way into the game. Buying all of the tables in Pinball Arcade may seem expensive to some people, but compared to the cost of owning dozens of actual pinball tables, it is extremely cheap. You can even play the table Tales of the Arabian Nights for free. Some of the tables are works of art in game form, and most people will not encounter pinball machines in their local area the way they used to up until the late 1990s.

The tables in Pinball Arcade are replicas of ones from the stables of Williams, Gottlieb, Bally, Stern, Data East, and Sega. Farsight Studios (the company behind Pinball Arcade) have produced a string of previous games that attempt to achieve authenticity and pay homage to the history and culture of pinball.

Pinball Arcade plays more like real pinball than any other pinball video game does. It manages to look fantastic without adding a layer of graphical effects that couldn't be incorporated into real tables. The tables appear mechanical, although they are of course simulated. The relatively accurate physics programmed in means the ball behaves quite realistically. I think most people who have played much real pinball would agree that Pinball Arcade is the closest simulation out, and the next best thing to real pinball.

Like most other pinball games, there is a lot crammed into an area that's a different shape to a landscape orientation monitor. Thankfully, in Pinball Arcade, you can swivel the monitor 90° into portrait mode if you have that kind of monitor. Even without this, the game is highly enjoyable and without doubt the best pinball video game yet made, in my opinion.

reviewText:
Yes I've only played this for X amount of minutes - I've seen others troll this on reviews. However this is a very special game you can't pass up at $14.99

Think of it this way you get the best of both worlds. Pinball Hall Of Fame Gotlieb Collection and Pinball Hall Of Fame Williams Collection from the PS2 system with some added tables that you may have heard of before. There are about 21 tables total from what I counted and all faithfully play to the original tables. However depending on your system , if you think you meet the system requirements - Be ready for slowdown at certain momemnts of the game if your system resolution is very very high. If your on a machine that barely go over the system requirements, do Windowed full screen mode at the highest screen res you can do, this will turn off V Sync and provide a more smooth experience at the cost of minor screen tearing.

I applaud Farsight Studios for bringing these games to the PC and this sale was killer but I was ultimately was dissapointed at the price point which may scare lots of people off due to its $30 price tag per pack. $4.99 is too expensive for individual tables that only give access to 2 tables most. That and the fact that you cant purchase these individual packs online through the Steam store it must be done online.

reviewText:
I've enjoyed pinball in actual arcades all my life, from the mid-80s up through today, and as someone who has played a lot of real pinball and a lot of digital interpretations of pinball (going back to David's Midnight Magic on the C-64) it's clear that Pinball Arcade is a labor of love. It is the closest I've ever come to playing a real pinball table in a virtual environment. While the game can't quite recreate all of the unusual ball physics you might see in a real table (such as smacking the ball against the topglass on freak bounces), it does as good a job as you could expect for a computer. Not only that, but you can always be sure that the parts for your table are in perfect working order, which is not something that can be said of random tables in an arcade.

Every table is not only lovingly reproduced here, but you get extras such as detailed instructions on how to play the table, how each game mode works and a general understanding that not only helps you in the game but if you encounter the real tables as well. With a bit of work, you can even play in portrait mode on a side-rotated monitor for a beautiful lengthened table experience. The still images on the store page here really don't do justice to the program in action.

The awesome part is that you don't have to just take my word for it; the game comes with Tales of the Arabian Nights for free, which allows you to really get a feel for what the game is capable of. The other tables have to be bought and on their own, the packs seem a bit on the pricy side (especially since I've never seen them on sale), but when you consider what you're getting, the cost per table is $1.50 or less--the cost of three plays in an actual arcade--which is really a steal when you consider what goes into the creation of each table. The Pro options open up some new features that are fantastic for true pinball afficionados, but for those who just want to play the tables as they might find them in an arcade (and not be able to switch things up as if they owned the table themselves), they aren't really necessary.

For those considering buying, Season 1 just slightly edges out Season 2 by virtue of having more tables as well as the inclusion of such greats as Bride of Pin-Bot and Twilight Zone. As of the time of this review, Season 3 is for sale but its contents haven't been decided. I actually own tables for the game on a console, so I haven't gotten around to picking them up on PC yet.

If you enjoy real or digital pinball, there's no reason that you shouldn't download this and give the free table included a shot.

reviewText:
Amazingly, the PC version is worse than the PS4 version.  As much as I looked forward to Pinball Arcade's PC release, I was equally disappointed at the poor quality of the release.  Bad lighting, no customizable camera movement, a lack of a decent operator menu for the tables and very shoddy, bug ridden or just plain incomplete translations of some games.

In addition, you have to create a separate account to keep track of leaderboard scores and you have to add money to your steam wallet to buy individual tables.  On top of this , they won't allow you to buy single tables so you're forced to get one table for $5 and you're often stuck with a second table you don't care about.

reviewText: If you ever visited arcades in the 70's, 80's, or 90's, this game is a main line to the nostalgia pleasure spot of your brain. With over 50 tables (and counting), you'll likely never be bored. Beyond that, it's pinball! These aren't fantasy tables, these are loving recreations of machines you'd be hard pressed to find in the wild today. Are they perfect? No. Do they play the same as the real thing? Well there's a world of difference between playing something fully mechanical with all the randomness of real world physics, and that of a digital version. That being said, it will improve your pinball IQ, and many times it comes damn close to being just like the real thing.\n\nA note on purchasing. Buy the seasons, as you are paying for 6 tables and getting 10. It's an even better deal for seasons 1 and 2. Yes, that might make the game seem expensive, but look at it more as if you are buying a new Madden every year, only the old seasons work side by side with the new. Seriously, $30 is not bad for a block of tables that will keep you busy for an entire year. Even better if you get 'em on sale!

reviewText:
What a massive disappointment this game is.

For someone who played and loved the original Williams machines back in the day, I was looking forward to this -- looking forward to reliving nights in the bar 25 years back, 99 cent ryes and guilt-free cigarettes, terrible 80s music, all the memories. You know, without the bar, the rye, or the cigarettes. Maybe some 80s tunes, if nobody's around.

I don't know how the makers of this game got the licenses to those Williams pinballs, but I really wish they hadn't. The execution here is barely adequate at every turn, in stark contrast to the overall excellent (which is something I never thought I'd say for a Microsoft Studios game) Pinball FX2. How is this game disappointing, specifically?

Well: the UI doesn't work properly, in addition to being just plain ugly. Try changing key bindings, if you want an exercise in frustration. There doesn't seem to be any nod whatsoever to the sorts of niceties that Steam supports, utterly unlike the incredibly well-done leaderboard/friend functionality in Pinball FX2. The physics are just... wrong. The ball doesn't react to 'gravity' in a convincing way, and it only takes seconds of play for the illusion to be broken. The ball shudders and strobes as it 'rolls' in exactly the sort of way a real ball doesn't. Textures are inconsistent, weirdly low-resolution all over the place, and the lighting model is... odd. The 'room' in which the pinball table stands sports textures right out of the early 90s. Maybe that's a sly nod to the time period, but I doubt it.

This is, as far as I can tell, a straight-across port of the iPad game, right down to the touch-centric interface. But a game that looked and sounded adequate on an iPad2, and was worth every cent of the price -- free -- just doesn't cut it on a modern gaming PC without an attempt at least a little polish.

Worst of all, if you're a Williams afficionado, at least, is that they utterly failed to capture the truly distinct and unique feel of Williams machine flippers. Which is doubly ironic, because in playing Pinball FX2 for the last week or so, one thing I actually said to myself was these flippers feel just like Williams' used to".

But to add insult to mediocrity

recommended: Pinbot! or Black Knight! -- the publishers of this game expect you to fork out $160 (Edit: 'only' $70 to $90

reviewText:
Classic Recreations of REAL Pinball Tables....That's all you need to hear. So many negative reviews for being too expensive, etc. Look people, these are recreations of ***REAL PINBALL MACHINES***, there are licensing fees, royalties, etc. involved here. If you want a real pinball machine, you're going to fork over a lot more money.

Ok, so the UI is awful, but they are improving it soon. Complaining about graphics quality on the PC? DX11 is coming. They've integrated SteamPlay and Linux is coming. Trust me, this company is not out on a cash grab. They are on a mission to recreate some of the best pinball tables ever made. They are a small shop with limited resources and it is what it is, but make no mistake, they are doing this for the love of Pinball.

Gameplay is 100x better than those *OTHER* games. And before you accuse me of being on their payroll, be known that I buy any and ALL pinball games and play them. I've been playing Pinball for 25 years and I enjoy it any way I can get it.

reviewText:
Really, I wanted to like this, right from the start. I've been waiting for a commercial effort for years - I've been playing VisualPinball since, huh, forever now.

Some years ago, I built a custom Pincab to be able to bring virtual pinball to the next level (using Visual Pinball as a platform of choice). I am sad to say, Pinball Arcade never managed to patch in any kind of satifying pincab support after all these years, which is kind of sad.

As for the game itself, I never managed to like the engine, the machines recreated rarely succeed in playing the same way their original counterpart did (I played most of them extensively in my material world) with a rare few exceptions.
Graphically the game is sub-par and very inconsistant between tables (some are plain ugly, some are really well done). I saw there was a DX11 update, but I had mixed success on playing it on my Pincab.

In-game camera placement is aweful when using a vertically oriented monitor and you've got to choose between unatural deep perspective and not-so-top down camera with missing flippers. Really ?

Regarding physical aspect of the game, I can't say it's bad, but it's not feeling like I'm playing a simulation either. I still prefer latest Visual Pinball's physics over this.

So mixed feelings - buying this is up to you, especially if you're playing on a pincab.

reviewText:
As a long-time serious pinball player, this looked like a really good idea. Why didn't anyone think of this before?

The sad fact of the matter is that if you are a competitive pinball player, you'll have a bad time with this. It simply will not feel even close to a real machine, especially when it comes to the nudging which I normally do quite a bit in real life. In this game, not so much, because it doesn't feel natural at all.

The physics are okay, but nowhere near as good as many people have said. Same thing here, if you are a casual pinball player, you might not notice, but the rest of us do. For example, the flippers in the game are bouncy as they should be, but they completely lack the rubbery friction which is so important when you're trying to catch the ball.

The controls are nowhere near as responsive as a pinball game requires. Tried with both a normal ♥♥♥♥♥♥ keyboard and an Xbox 360 controller. The controller was better, but it simply wasn't possible for me to play with the keyboard.

reviewText:
O.K.  I've played enough of this game to get a general impression of the quality.  I had downloaded it years ago but thought the price of the packs were too high so I uninstalled it.  I recently got an urge to play pinball so I purchased Pinball FX2 as it was cheaper and had good reviews.  While Pinball FX2 is a good game (I bought about eight tables), I found it a bit gimmicky.  I had only played the free Arabian table on Pinball Arcade and thought it was O.K. but it wasn't enough to convince me to spend the bucks to buy a pack.  But I did some research and read some reviews and in the end I took the plunge and bought Season Pack One.  Boy am I glad I did because it is really good.  The authenticity of the tables I find amazing and it has to be as close to playing the real classic pinball tables on a pc as you can get.  I found Pinball FX2 to be more flash over substance where as Pinball Arcade is more of a passion of love.  I read some reviews complaining about a 'delay' in the flippers but that is all part of the authenticity.  On the old pinball machines it was all mechanical so it would seem like a 'delay' anyway because of the moving parts.

As for the price, for the £22.99 or so I paid for pack one, I got about 21 tables so that works out at about a pound per table which is very good value for money.  The price may seem high but it is totally worth it.  A single table on Pinball FX2 starts at about £1.99 so it is a no-brainer.

I'm just pretty amazed by the realism of the tables - very impressive !

Edit (4/5/2016)

After some more game time I am updating my review.  I have now tried out a lot of the tables on Pinball Arcade and whilst they are still very good, my only gripe is that they seem to all be retro tables.  I wish there were more modern tables but all the tables seem to be pre-1980's.  Anyway, I played Pinball FX2 some more and found a table view I liked and after playing it some more I found it to be more enjoyable than previously thought and not so gimmicky.

So my final conlusion is if you want a retro and realistic pinball simulator with lots of classic tables, than Pinball Arcade is the one to go for, but if you want modern mechanics and tables, then Pinball FX2 is the one to go for.

reviewText:
Hi everyone, a little history then I'll move on.... Growing up, I had a huge interest in Computers and Video Games. However my true passion was always Pinball. My first computer was a commodore 64 which I got for Christmas of 1983. The first real game I purchased for the C64 was EA's Pinball Construction Set  PC Link Here [www.myabandonware.com].  It was simple as hell, but still you were able to create multiball games with it.

About 10 years ago I was introducted to Visual Pinball which blew my mind, free pinball tables that can be created by everyone and anyone with an interest and started out banging tables I remembered creating in the 80's using PCS, then onto Future pinball and anything else that tried to recreate that feeling of real play.

Fast forward to today and we have finally have TPA on the PC and nothing out there has yet to even come close to this;  I mean it may not be perfect (DX11), I can think of many things that should be added (Cabinet Mode.) However it has been a start to a near perfect Authenic Collection of pinball tables recreated for the PC.

One addition I would love to see with TPA is side by side double player action with my steam friends, where each player plays on the left or right side of the screen, multi screen or even each player having its own window. I cannot see it taking up much bandwith and this would be excellent for tournaments and competition events. Are there any others who share this same type of interest.

Here is a some Canadian Badass trivia. What do I have tattoo'd on my back?

reviewText:
This game is being totally murdered by greed and inept marketing.
While it manages - just about - to stand comparison with Pinball FX2 in terms of gameplay, the visible table size and viewing angles are poorer.
What really kills this stone dead though, is the inability to purchase on a table-by-table basis. You have to pay for a multi-table 'Season pack' or forget it.
Therefore, I recommend you forget it. A pity, as some of the all-time classic tables are in here. Sadly, a lot of the all-time dogs are too.

reviewText: Avoid this version of Pinball Arcade. It is a straight port from iOS and is optimized horribly for the PC platform. The menus and interface are clearly made to work on a touch screen devices and doesn't feel right on a keyboard and mouse. Graphics could be improved, as well as the audio which sounds incredibly compressed. That being said, the tables and physics are outstanding, and the attention to detail in this area is really impressive. There are tons of tables to choose from, from many different eras and manufacturers. If you can look past the subpar optimization, definitely give it a try, but there are better platforms to play this game on.

reviewText:
The initial VERY long delay for the game's PC release (and also DX 11 update later) put aside: The Pinball Arcade is in my opinion a dream come true for everyone who enjoys playing pinball casually to semi-professionally.

As the developer advertises, this is not just a collection of virtual pinball tables, but an accurate simulation of real tables, making TPA also a project of history preservation, as most of these tables are not produced anymore and fewer of them exist with every passing year.

TPA does of course not replace the real table experience, but the simulation is getting very close to it: every surface is scanned, every part recreated as a 3D model and every software of a table is emulated (including sounds, displays, ect.). Classic and licensed tables from all the big pinball companies can be found here, including Williams, Stern, Midway and Bally.

The developer keeps improving the game's physics and the interface is planned to improve in the future too.

Tales of the Arabian Nights is always available for free and every other table can also be tested for free until players reach a certain score. There's also always another free table available each month. You can compete with your scores in a global ranking or a seperate ranking just with the people on your friends list.

If you are new to the game or pinball tables in general: download the demo, play a few games of Tales of the Arabian Nights and test all the other tables. If you are unsure which season pack you should buy, my advice would be to start with season 1, which is still the most solid mix in my opinion.

reviewText: Pinball Arcade brings back the classic tables from the old days. Yes you will have to pay for the tables. With Steams enhancements it is easy to now have friends join you from home. Come on over, sit down, and pull out the joystick. Grab coffee, biscuit and headphones and let the fun begin. Just remember to stop and deal with the real world after awhile of playing. Life still goes on outside of the game.

reviewText:
The graphics may not be perfect, but what you do get are two things no other pinball game has:

1. The ball physics is phenomenal, going back to other pinball games after playing PA demonstrate just how close Farsight have got to the real thing and how waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy off the mark certain other pinball games are.

2. These are great recreations of real tables running the original software, if you like pinball and don't have a few grand to drop on a real machine then a few quid for some of the best tables of all time is peanuts for what you get in terms of actual play time and satisfaction.

Download it, play it in portrait mode with a monitor flat on a table,

I recommend these tables - Monster Bash, Star Trek, Terminator 2, Attack from Mars.

Just a great great game and a great service to pinball fans by a devoted small studio.

Very very highly recommended

reviewText:
The most expensive free game ever.

Once you download all 3.5GB of this game, you are immediately presented with text telling you how awesome this game is (?) and then you are asked to purchase minimum of one (1.) pinball table for a small sum of 5 euroes. Of course, you can get a package that saves you TON OF MONEY, by paying about 25 euroes and receiving 10 tables.

If you do not pay, you can play effectively for about 5 minutes of time since there is a highscore cap you can reach before the game boots you out, but hey, you are able to repeat this countless of times!
You cannot save your highscore since you haven't payed, but there is one (1.) free table you can play.

There are aparently some other free tables, which you have to find in the sea of pay to play ones, but I managed it. After I found one free table, it also asked me to purchase it. Bug or feature, I have no idea.

The game itself is not that bad, graphics and gameplay are both decent. Camera is a bit tricky on some tables because it automatically follows the ball to certain edge of the table, making it really awkward to use the flippers as the ball comes back. Controls are quite simple and easy to use, although they are not what I would assume them to be.

Overall:
If you are not a pinball fanatic who has mountains of cash to burn, I recommend avoiding this game.


EDIT1 - For the developers:

The game is pretty bad with its current system, however, it has potential.
Here are some of things I believe should be done in order to sell the game better and make it more successful:

1. Remove the message on start up. No one likes a self brag.
2. Cut the game and sell it. The game doesn't really need 3.5GB to operate, when a person that downloads it uses only 1 table. Also, why is this game free? It obviously is made with the intention to sell and that is alright. Put the price on the game, 5eur. Comes with 5 tables, Nothing else. Make DLC's containing 10 tables each that would upgrade to the game and sell them at whatever price you wish.
3. Release a Demo. Allow players to download a free demo, containing only 1 free table - how it comes now.
4. Do not bug the players to purchase ingame. It is offsetting. A simple For more tables check out our DLC packages on Steam!" would do.
5. Once all of the above has been done
date: promote. Give out a few cheap/free copies via bundles for example.\n\nGood luck."

reviewText:
I've had tons of fun with Pinball Arcade (I own Pinball Hall of Fame on Wii, then Xbox 360, and now Pinball Arcade on PS4 & PC). These tables are recreated with a great amount of detail. It's not quite as good as reality, of course, but this is the best we have. There are so many nostalgic sounds and sights. These tables can give you hundreds of hours of fun!

The cost of all the DLC packs really add up, if you care to collect them all, but this game is absolutely unique.

Note, Pinball Arcade are based on real world tables. There is no fantasy element. Pinball FX2 exists for fake pinball tables, and there isn't really any Kirby/Pokemon/Sonic-style fantasy pinball game anymore (WizOrb is Arkanoid style but similar).

reviewText:
Awesome game.

For free you get a Pinball table and each month they rotate a free table to play as well.

The free table they give you is pretty decent but the amount of tables there are to purchase can make it a bit confusing trying to figure out which ones will be the most fun- Each table has a trial but its too limited to really be able to see how 'good' it will be for you... First world problems, I know. =P

I purchased 2 tables (bride of Pinbot and medieval madness) on a recomendation for like $4.99 for both and imho these tables were a steal. If I would have just tried these boards on the trial I wouldnt have bought them because the amount of time it takes to really see how the board works is much more than the trial gives you.

So, I would recomend asking people who've played or watching some youtube videos before picking what to buy because it really can be confusing.

As far as how good these tables are compared to  the originals they are based on- I have no idea. I've never played much pinball (real or virtual) so all i can comment on is the fun factor for me- Ive been playing with my wife (who isnt a gamer) and we've been having a blast- For under $5.00 we got 3 really good tables (theres sooooo much to do on each table that even just having a couple would not get boring) and the monthly table to try (which I dont like at all) and I'm very happy.

Needs to have an easier way of setting up a verticle monitor because I'm lost at how to do that but other than that thois is fantastic.

Will be making further purchases -

reviewText:
Single-handedly reinvigorated my love of pinball.  I used to play a whole bunch of these tables when arcades were still a thing.  Yes, I'm old.  Shut up.

I know some people complain that it's not the same thing, and I agree.  It's never going to be an exact 100% recreation.  It's never going to be like plunking a quarter into Whirlwind.  You know what?   I'm fine with that because it's a damn good representation.  If nothing else, having things like the instructions really has upped my game.  When I play IRL pinball, I'm way better.

One problem might be the price, for some people.  Pinball Arcade is not cheap.  I started playing it on my PS3, bought three seasons and then realized I'd have to re-buy the same tables when I migrated to Steam.  Thank god for sales.  I can't particularly complain because the people who make these tables are talented, but it could be a sticking point for some.  If you like pinball, though, it's a must buy.

reviewText:
HOLY. COW.

I've always enjoyed pinball games. Unfortunately, given the fact I live in a very rural area I've always had to make do with video game pinball tables, only having played real physical units a time or three. Despite that the history and design of the real tables have always fascinated me, and I've longed for a way I could experience some of the real classics.

Well, here's the answer.

In terms of production values as a video game Pinball Arcade is a little lacking in some areas. Overall visual fidelity isn't the greatest given the simplicity of its subject matter, and in all honesty the presentation of the game's menus isn't the most user friendly, with a strangely syrupy-feeling lag between menu selection inputs and their taking effect on-screen. In-game, though, things are completely different, with tight controls and a solidly reliable camera that makes actually playing the tables themselves a joy. Perhaps its simply my inexperience, but the physics of the tables do, at times, feel a bit on the floaty side, however.

What really takes the cake in the game's presentation, at least for me, are the snippets of table background available when you launch each table. For players just looking to play some pinball these might seem like a bit of an annoyance, but for those who appreciate the history of the industry, or the history of games in general, these blurbs are fascinating and offer insight into the development of pinball games as a whole.

The visual issues and physics mentioned above are nitpicky issues, but part of what makes them stand out is the price of the overall package. At thirty dollars or more a pop for each season
date: or five dollars a piece to buy tables individually, the tables in Pinball Arcade feel like they come at a stomach-churning premium, especially when compared to its competitors. Doubtless the premium is partially due to licensing costs for the various tables from their original producers, but when alternatives like Pinball FX offer cheaper tables with arguably (from a video game perspective) more complex gameplay and higher production values, it can be hard to justify to oneself the pricing here. That said, there's something to be said for featuring real" tables as opposed to completely unrealistic fantasy models
recommended: and when the content of each season is taken into account the price discrepancy isn't as great as it at first seems
hoursPlayed: since each season consists of 10 or more unique tables
voteText: meaning tables average out to about 3 dollars a pop if the basic version of each season is purchased
helpfulPercent: less for the Season 1 tables since there are 14 of them.\n\nIf you're a pinball aficionado

votesTotal: and I would highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates more about game design than just the latest graphics engine and online shooting. The tables play nicely
votesFunny: and the extras make for a unique
commentsCount: well-valued package. If
column16: on the other hand
column17: you're turned off by the idea of solid-state hardware and often incredibly dated table aesthetics

I really wanted to like this game since after moving to a new place I had to get rid of my pinballs but unfortunately, I will have to wait for something better.

reviewText:
Sorry for the lack of focus of the review, just writing this up as I go.

Pinball has always been part of our gaming culture. It's technically the grandfather of all modern video games, mechanical pinball was the first arcade game. They've been around longer then any video arcade game. They're an important part of not just gaming culture, but the entertainment industry, right up there with any other fine art. And if you think about it, the amazing effort put into every specific machine is extraordinary. Just imagine putting all those little gears and lights and gizmos together, so someone can slap some flippers around to get a high score.

Anyways, enough about my praise of the pinball machine and onto the review. Farsight has done an excellent job recreating over 40 pinball tables (to date) and releasing them in virtual form. There has been other attempts at true 3d virtual pinball recreations, mostly those PS2 games, but the amount of tables to choose from was small, and the graphics, quite poor. They were poor representations of the tables. Now, why should the casual game be interested in this? Because simply put, the pinball experience is something unique to it. If you have not already tried a pinball table before, a *REAL* one, not something like Pinball FX, then you should defintely download the demo and try out the free table of the week. It's a real treat to see everything about the IRL machine recreated in minute detail. The lights the ramps the targets the animitronics, the dialogue, the dot matrix displays, and the charm of even the older mechanical machines are all recreated virtually.

Like I've said, you've got over 40 tables to choose from, with another 20 tables planned for release in 2014. Let me go over how the game isn't really free to play, but more like an actual paid game. You can buy individual tables for 4.99 each. Some of the tables are surely worth it, you've got legendary classics like Medieval Madness, Terminator 2, and quirky and rare tables like Cactus Canyon, and Going Nuts. You've got tables from all eras, old electro mechanical pins like Genie, and some of the more early released 1980s efforts by Balley like Black Knight and Class of 1812, both of which I highly reccomend, picking them up via the season 1 pack. The season packs cost 29.99 and come with 20 tables each. You're only paying for a few dollars per table, but if you want you can pick up individual tables of the more popular ones like T2 and Medieval Madness for 5 dollars each. I do not reccomend picking up the Pro pack, for 2 extra dollars you get a small change to the ini file and the option to access to the operator menu. Which also invalidates your score.

Comparsions to Pinball FX2 can and will be made. Pinball FX is notably cheaper.. you can get Humble Bundle keys which contain 2/3 of the tables for a dollar. But a majority of the tables are Marvel liscenced virtual pins made only for the game. And a lot of them don't have very fun goals. Take a look at Farsights virtual repesentation of Funhouse on Pinball Arcade, which came out in 1990, side by side with Zen Studio's newest lisceneced table from Marvel, Dr. Strange and you'll see the difference. Funhouse is 20 years older and 20 times more fun. This is because the table's featured in Pinball Arcade are much better designed, have more satisfying rewards, and have a snappier pace.

Virtual pinball in itself is a niche, but a niche defintely worth trying out. It's actually quite accessable, unlike most games that are niche - rougelikes for example. I would reccomend anyone with a passing interest to try out the game (Dont think its free to play, its defintely not, but they provide one fully functional table every month.) If you've played a pinball machine in your life, and you enjoyed it, download this game and give it a try.

reviewText:
The PC version is the best TPA for sounds and table art.
The console versions sound is crappy most notible is High-Speed my PS4 versions when it does the bonus after just a short while the sound for the bonus just ends and it goes silent.
With the PC version it is more true to the real thing.

I should know I own High-Speed here.

The Pros: Great visuals and sound.
Play the tables on here then look for them out in the wild!

The Cons: Nothing beats the real thing you do not get the feel of the table and the mechs working and the feel of the ball while it zips around.
Ball is pretty much glued to the playfield. No ball hopping like in a real machine which I love!
And I noticed unlike the console versions the PC version only has the Season Packs for sale and not individual which is a bummer.

reviewText:
As a pinball enthusiast, this game is satisfying.

I've purchased a few select tables (Theatre of Magic, Black Hole, Ripley's Believe it or Not) and have really enjoyed them. They do an excellent job simulating the sights/sounds that you remembered from these wonderful machines.
The physics feel very real, but there will never be quirks that develop as these simulators will never show wear and tear.

I've trial-played most of the tables, and the one I'm very disappointed in is the White Water. This is an excellent game in person (continue to play) with a much nicer tri-color backlight display and the sound effects of this simulation game are atrocious.

Overall though, this has been an excellent and fun experience. I've showed my kids that this is really fun stuff and even cooler in person! (albeit more difficult for sure)

A++ guys; keep the tables coming! I've also heard that you'll be teaming up with Stern (maybe Jersey Jack) to co-release new tables with their simulators??? That's the ticket! Get this younger generation to realize the magic and fun of playing these universes of wonder on the 2D screens, and then the real-life version will be that much better.

reviewText:
This is over six GIGABYTES worth of pinball.

You get one table/level for free, but every one of the tables in this thing is the most accurate possible recreation of an actual pinball table that was sold at some point.  If you remember a pinball table from your childhood, there's a chance it's in here somewhere.  You can play each of the other tables once-ish for free, and after that it's a set price to unlock one permanently.

If you like pinball as much as most people like football, this is the pinball game for you.

The free table isn't bad, though pretty hectic.

reviewText:
Pinball Arcade is not a perfect game (but is perfectible for sure), however it is a work of pure passion and it deserves a great consideration from the community of pinball players.

It is better than its rival Pinball Fx2 for several reasons (that unfortunately I can't afford here for my poor english), now the tables selection is huge and  destined to grow again and the feel that it recreates is the right one.

Of course I'd like to have more and confortable table views (maybe a free camera), a lot of detailed statiscals in every table (in this aspect Pinball Fx2 is far superior), a better leaderbord/ranking function, the avaibility of tournament for Steam platform, a time mode to challenge my friends and so on but I hope/I'm quite sure that in future patches we'll have great improvements.

So thumb is up!

reviewText: I've probably played every Pinball game in existence on various systems but to me The Pinball Arcade" is easily the best of them all. No need for Gimmics or Special FX it's as close as you can get without playing the actual Pinball table. Although come to think of it sometimes it's better because there's no dodgy flipper or bad reflections as many Arcades place the tables (in the UK at least) too close to a window.\n\nThe DX11 version is the Mutts Nutts (or DB if you prefer !) and with season 5 upon us there are now over 40 tables available. Sure there are a few crap one's but with 3 of my all time arcade favourites in Fish Tales
date: The Getaway High Speed 2 & Funhouse faithfully reproduced I can't really complain.\n\nThe interface is getting a bit clunky now with the number of tables available as you have to scroll through a long list to find the table of your choice. Perhaps a future update will address this with search options or being able to arrange the tables by say season
recommended:
year or manufacturer as well as a favourites option. When the disc versions of Pinball Arcade
Hall of Fame came out on PS2 & Wii all the tables were represented in an Arcade with so many tables in each room which worked well so something along those lines would be good as well. My only real gripe is the Pro version of the tables which is just a rip off. Why not make them available for free if you achieve all the wizard goals on a table ?.

Above all it's so much fun to play and although I'm a seasoned player I still get frustrated when a ball drains unexpectedly or I tilt the table just short of my all time high score !. But that's what it's all about realistic gameplay that draws you in to having another go. I'm sure you won't regret buying it but I would wait for a sale before buying the earlier seasons. Who know you may get as good as me with lots of practice but I doubt it ! :)."

reviewText:
It's difficult to give a simple 'Yes' or 'No' for Pinball Arcade. I really enjoy playing the actual tables and if you are pulled towards nostalgia then its great. The biggest problem I have is with the ball physics, but even that isn't a simple good or bad. Some of the tables, like Bride of Pinbot, play great. Other tables, like Funhouse and Tales of Arabian Nights, have terrible physics and the ball seems to defy gravity, floating all around the table. I have seen some people trying to argue that all of the tables play great with real physics; can only assume they live on the moon. It is something you get used to, but it does make it hard to track the ball and makes for readjusting when switching back to a better table. I am surprised they made Tales of Arabain Nights the free table as it is a complete turn-off. This tells me the company is in complete denial if they think that table is good and a sales conviner
. I actually didn't buy the Season packs until I read that some tables have great physics and others, like Tales, are terrible. There are also some issues with camera angles being not always the greatest choices especially if you don't want the camera to jump around and track the ball (I'm not a fan of that). I've noticed some tables, like Theater of Magic, have times where they are choppy for a second or two while most run smoothly all of the time.
Overall, I recommend this to a pinball fan. I pretty much consider a handfull of the tables (Funhouse and Tales of Arabian Nights for instance) and won't touch them. I'm not sure if they will ever correct the physics for those and I am not sure as to why different tables have better physics than others.
If you are new to pinball, I think Pinball FX is much better with consistently smooth physics. After that, if the pinball bug bites,  try Pinball Arcade, but you should check out something other than the free game.

reviewText:
This game is a dream come true for me. I played pinball on real machines when I was a few years younger and since I discovered it first on Android a few months ago, it's easily the game I've spent most time on this year.

Why is it so good (and what is not so good)?

These pinball tables are all digital versions of original tables. Farsight spends a lot of effort into realistic physics, ROM emulations, digitalising the artwork etc. You can feel, they are pinball enthusiasts. I might not be an expert for all pinball games on the market. I tested a few, but this was exactly what I was looking for. Most pinball games have features, which are impossible on a real table, especially when you look at Pinball FX2 in comparison. I will come back to FX2 later in this review.

reviewText:
I was very impressed with this title. The recreation of some of the more popular and fondly remembered pinball machines is very accurately done. Every sound, graphic and animation you remember has been faithfully reproduced.

In short, it's everything you want a pinball game to be!

Now for the negative; The menu graphics and fonts are large and clunky, and in general not very visually appealing, and changing graphic settings can only be done outside of the game, but both of these aspects can be largely ignored.

The main downfall of this game is however, is pricing. While, for a pinball game, it hits all of the right sweet spots, to be able to play more than just one table, you need to spend a heck of a lot.

To buy Season One (to essentially convert your Demo" into a full game)
date: it costs almost twice the price of Skyrim! Which is just not on.\n\nDo I recommend this title? Everything in me wants so desperately to say yes
recommended: as it's probably one of the nicest pinball games I've had the pleasure of playing
hoursPlayed: but I'm afraid this gets a no from me. Simply for the fact that I can't justify the pricing. I would have loved to play more of it otherwise.\n\nI'll be happy to change this review and recommend this title if the pricing is ever fixed. But until then
voteText: steer clear."

reviewText:
This impressive collection of authentic tables boasts an exceptional fun factor. Most of these landmark arcade tables are professionally well recreated with a staggering attention to detail in glorious 1080p. Yes, many complained that you have to pay for additional tables - and pro packs might be costly for what they really give. Multiplayer ( tournaments ) and DirectX11 features also not available at the release, only later in 2014.  Otherwise gameplay remains rock solid, fluid, physics quite decent,  though as any video pinball  we might sometimes feel gravity/ball weight not as severe as real tables ( thus developers targeting a wider community ). At the same time, experts still need to work hard in order to level up in the leaderboards and completing some challenging 'wizard goals'.

Pros:  package of authentic and licensed tables; a blast to play; beautiful and detailed graphics; wide array of goals to achieve.

Cons ( minor ) : gravity/ball physics not always as realistic as purists would have liked; no tournaments several weeks after release.

reviewText: The Pinball Arcade is without any doubt, some of the best virtual pinball I've played. From it's fluid and realistic ball physics to the attention to details given to the large selection of tables available, it's easy to see why this latest Farsight release as been so highly praised. A collection of some of pinball's most famous tables are at your fingertips, and you're spoilt for choice with legendary tables such as Star Trek The Next Generation, Black Hole, Terminator 2, Bride of Pin-Bot and Theatre of Magic to name just a few. Plus there's the added bonus of the fact that you can experience the Tales of the Arabian Nights table absolutely free of charge.\n\nYes there are other pinball games available, but no other features tables based on their actual real life counterpart and none even come close to being able to match how it plays a game of Pinball. There are improvements that need to be made, but you really can't go wrong with giving this one a try. If you a pinball fan, it's a must play.

reviewText: Just like ships without rudders are not worth commanding, so are most modern video games not worth playing. With outstanding graphics (in color), I was able to replay pinball tables before the creation of the INTERNET.  For those that enjoy hitting steel balls with flippers, this game is a must, and high scores are recorded on the line.  For being the top pinball king, it is not enough that I succeed; others must fail!!!

reviewText:
What makes this game worthwhile is the faithful recreations of actual pinball tables. The tables are pretty spendy, but it is probably justified by licensing costs. The engine itself is pretty good, but the ball moves faster and feels lighter than it would on an actual pinball table, even immaculate condition machines, which I have played a few. This is only a minor annoyance and the pitch perfect tables are worth the price of admission. The first season is far and away the best deal and has most of the tables you would want anyways.

The package is far from perfect however. The UI is awful and little has been done to update it for this platform which really hurts the overall package. The lack of integration with Steam is a missed opportunity considering competing for a high score is a big draw to pinball.

If you love playing actual pinball, this game is for you.

If nostalgia isn't part of the package for you, you may be better served with Pinball FX2 which boasts friendslist integration so you can easily see how your friends did on each table and try to beat their top score (which is the reason FX2 is getting more play time from me these days).

reviewText:
Would be great Only for real Pinball machine fans.  Free to try.  Comes free with full version of Tales of the Arabian Nights pinball machine.
Free to Play one pinball machine and the rest are trial runs. Trial run of pinball machine are score limited and single player, no options.

Four seasons of pinball machines to buy, season one has 21 machines in it (price 29.99 or 39.99) or buy a table pack with the pinball machine you want.

Has a DX11 video mode and a lower video mode.  Each pinball machine looks like and acts like a digital simulation of a real life pinball machine. Except you are not able to see the real scoreboard while playing, and your camera tends to slowly follow the ball( had lost some balls by not seeing the flipper in time) .  Not sure if the physics are really correct compared to real game.  Not sure if you can influence the table like you can in real life.  The flippers seem slow and not as powerfull.

Has an online leaderboard and steam achievements.

I don't really like real pinball games so i am deleting after reviewing.

reviewText: If you like pinball at all, most of these tables are a must have. This is as close as you are going to get to perfect pinball on a PC outside a cabinet based sim, and then I'd probably recommend still using this software. I've been able to scratch my pinball itch with all these tables. I've purchased two seasons worth of tables for no small amount of money. I've spent more cash on this game than any other for the last several years. The physics are spot on and most of your typical pinball strategies are applicable. Many of the tables virtualized in this game are quite rare and hard to get to play. Some are great playing and not very popular in the arcades (aka Black Rose). While there is no real substitute for a real table, this is pretty good way to relive some of your favorite tables. Black Rose, Medieval Madness, Star Trek, Bride of Pinbot, and Adams Family are just a few of the ones I recommend you try out. All tables have a certain amount of free play in order to try them.

reviewText: This is the best pinball video game that I've ever played.   The physics and table dynamics feel true to life.  Playing on tables from my childhood is a huge plus as well.  I find the menues and addons surrounding the game to be a bit ugly and janky,  but the pinball is immaculate.  My only other complaint is that buying tables can be a bit expensive for my taste, but maybe I'm just cheap.  Overall, if you are even casually interested in pinball, this is by far the best that you're going to get.

reviewText:
Nothing can ever fully replicate the tactile experience of playing on a real pinball machine. But given how high-maintenance real tables are, plus how expensive they are in the first place, I am very, very happy that The Pinball Arcade exists.

It's not perfect (Cirqus Voltaire, my favorite table ever, needs some serious work on ball physics and Juggler Multiball), but this is BY FAR the best pinball sim out there.

But if you're reading this: If you ever find a real machine, even if it's not one of these, please give it a try. There is absolutely nothing else like pinball, and I'm so glad Farsight is helping keep this pastime alive.

reviewText:

reviewText:
With over 300+ hours now invested in this game, I can now safely say that Pinball Arcade comes as close as you can to actual pinball play as any simulation or game on the PC today, Pinball FX, and Pro Pinball included. If I were to break this review down in scores of 1 to 10, I would give each of the following these scores:

Presentation: 8/10 - A wide range of tables, producers, styles, and time frames of pinball, from the basic bell & whistle games to the more recent electronic gems like Addams Family. My down marks for this is that the PC version does not include the history of pinball videos that the Android version does, which to me greatly enhances the package, or lack thereof.

Graphics: 8/10 - Since Farsight got the licenses for these tables, their dedication to accuracy shows. Some pieces are missing, (Christopher Lloyd - Addams Family), due to contractual agreements, but wherever possible, FS has stuck as close to the original design of the table as they can. There was recently an update to DirectX 11, and if you have the system to run it, the graphical improvement is definitely noticeable.

Gameplay: 7.5/10 - Gameplay only suffers IMO due to an over adbundance of the need to nudge" or shake a table
date: and if you are someone like myself who doesn't use this 'ability'
recommended: the tables seem to penalize you by the ball consistently draining on side lanes
voteText: and a general REPEAT of the same ball play even in multiple player games. Also
helpfulPercent: as Steam Achievements are included in PA

votesTotal: it seems as the difficulty is somehow magically increased
votesFunny: thus making further achievements difficult if not almost impossible (Addams Family Super Bear Bonus for example). Aside from this each table has its on nuances and tricks
commentsCount: from Terminator 2

column23: the most popular pinball table in history
column24: Addams Family.\n\nPrice: 6/10 - As has been mentioned in other reviews

reviewText: I came to Pinball Arcade for one reason alone:  Twilight Zone.  Its my favorite pinball machine by far.  Imagine my delight when I found out that it could be purchased and played legally.  My elation was short lived when I saw the prices for the Pinball Arcade tables.  Even though the table packs would have to drop 75-90% for me to even consider purchasing them I figured I could just pick up Twilight Zone for a fiver and be done with it.  Fortunately for me I tried the TZ table before purchasing.  It is not the same game that I am familiar with.  The visuals are pretty close but the sounds are way off.  And these inaccuracies are present on other licensed property tables.  If I am going to pay out the nose I expect a product as advertised.\n\nNormally I would wait for a Steam sale and pick it up on the cheap but it appears these DLC packs never go on sale.  Maybe they will lower the price once the developers squeeze out the die-hard pinball wizards.  In the end the issues that surround Pinball Arcade make it a no-brainer uninstall.

reviewText:
When I was young, pinballs (the real thing) were easy to find, and I truly loved them.
Later, they were removed from bars, to make place for gambling machines (not as entertaining for me).

But I remember my favourite pinball, Bride of the Pin-Bot (remembered the name thanks to this game :D).

Pinball Arcade, although it can be expensive, lets me go back to those years, with almost the same feeling and the same sounds and challenges.
Buying all tables is very expensive, but the game lets you also buy individual tables, to get the ones you like more and just disregard the ones that you really don't want to play.

reviewText:
I'm a pinball fan from way back, so I was excited to hear about this title, and real world tables modeled? Icing on the cake.  Sadly however, icing is all this really is.  I was underwhelmed by the ball physics, which felt rather ping-pong ball light, and the flipper action lacked weight.  Worse still - the inability to intuitively set the view to a simple overhead that doesn't require any screen flipping was a complete deal killer for me.  It's possible I suppose, that the ability to put the view the way I want it does exist - and if someone would like to point it out to me, I'll give this another fair shot.  But for now? It was uninstalled very quickly indeed and I've no plans to return to it.

With that said - pinball still kicks ♥♥♥. So what to do?  I have one word for you : timeshock!   The ProPinball series of original pinball tables is the absolute gold standard for computer-based pinball as far as I'm concerned, and that opinion hasn't changed in over a decade.  Head over to Greenlight and check out the HD editions they're currently trying to put to the light of day.  If you love pinball - these guys deserve your support unreservedly.

Other alternatives - the Pinball FX2 on Steam is in most cases, acceptable and entertaining, though not exceptional. If you absolutely have to have your real-world modeled pinball?  Google PinMAME and do a little research.  It's more work to set up, but it'll get you the real-world tables you crave.

reviewText:
Although it's advertised as a free to play game, Pinball Arcade is simply a giant Demo that comes with 50+ recreated pinball tables, but only lets you play one table fully. The other 50 tables that came downloaded can only be played until you hit a high score and then you're kicked out, although you're allowed to replay them as many times as you want.

If you're downloading this looking for a free game to waste a couple of hours on, then it shouldn't matter since you can still have fun flailing the tables around with the tilting feature, and if you end up losing all your balls before you hit a high score then the limits won't be a real issue for you.

The problem is that after a while you just get tired of the game, there's no way for you to move on or unlock any more tables freely. Taking out highscores leaves you with really no point to replay a table or try to improve. Instead you feel punished for improving. It's like minigolf, the worse you are, the longer you get to play it. The better you are at getting points, the faster you'll be kicked out off the tables.
I wish the free version of the game would give you more. I'd love it if you could unlock one more free table by completing achievements, or even just being able to choose backround music to replace the silence/crappy music of some pinball tables.

When you go to buy a table, it just feels unneedlessly complicated to give three options of buying, but none of them let you just buy the single table you want! Your choices are to buy the 30$ season pack, a 5$ pack for 2 tables, and then ussually a 8$ Pro" pack version that never has it's differences explained ingame.
You're out of luck if you just want a single table in the pack
date: and the second table included is one that you couldn't care less about. There's not much flexibility with your choices or any real alternatives to that
recommended: and it just doesn't feel like a value if part of the price you're paying is for a table you'll never use.\n"

reviewText: I want to like The Pinball Arcade. Sure, their purchasing model is terrible but they've improved the physics dramatically since I first tried it and the game really is fun to play. I can get past the poor UI, frustrating lack of Steam leaderboards, and dated lighting; but what really kills it for me is that not only are textures inexplicably low resolution in some places, but there's visible jpeg compression artifacts all over the place. That's so egregiously unprofessional I can't even. It's the kind of issue I'd be willing to overlook in a Visual Pinball table, but in a commercial (and expensive) product? Not acceptable in the slightest.

reviewText: Pinball Arcade is a little different from most digital pinball games in that all of the tables are replicas, or near replicas of real classic pinball tables. This fact is one of the reasons I like the game so much, it helps though that not only are real tables in the game but there are brief but detailed descriptions of each table along with a snippet of the the tables history. The game features one free table, and lets you play the others as a trial before you decide if you want to purchase them, a feature common with most pinball games at this time. Pinball Arcade is free so if you like Pinball you should at least give this game a try, you never know you might learn something about pinball along the way.

reviewText:
PInball has been around for well over a decade longer than video games, and has evolved in interesting fashions over the years. And for almost as long as there have been video games, there have been video games attempting to bring the pinball experience into a video game.

For my entire life, I've played pinball, and tried pinball video games. None of them came close - they could not adequately imitate the freedom of a steel ball rolling freely across a painted wooden table, hitting things, and bouncing back out. They made games that looked like pinball, but didn't feel like Pinball. Even the Pinball FX series, as good as it is, still doesn't feel like a real ball spinning across a table freely.

Pinball Arcade is the first game I've ever felt came as close as possible to what pinball is. And they do this not by imitating pinball, but by digitizing pinball - by taking real pinball tables, and scanning them - not just taking pictures of the machines, but by taking them apart and scanning each and every part fully and completely - not just how the parts look, but how they weigh, feel, and act. As a result, they end up doing what other pinball games never have - they make the game feel very, very close to playing the same pinball table as you would find in an arcade. The tables offered are recreations of the same tables, and for all but a minor detail, they feel the same.

I have a hard time believing that any video game pinball can get the same tactile feel that true pinball tables have, and this is the one aspect that Pinball Arcade doesn't adequately duplicate. But they're closer than any other video game pinball has ever been - as close as I believe is possible. But if it's possible to take that last step, and get the same tactile sensation of having the ball roll across the table and feel the faint vibrations in your hands... I think that the team at Farsight Studios are the people who can make it happen.

The only downside that Pinball Arcade has right now is that their core UI for selecting tables is based on a touch-screen or controller system, and doesn't work cleanly with a computer's mouse-based interface, and almost doesn't work at all by keyboard. This is supposedly being updated and revamped soon, though, so I don't really mark them down too hard on this. The gameplay - when you're actually playing the pinball machine - is still very well-done.

If you like real-life pinball, this is the game you want to play.

reviewText:
ahhhh Nostalgia.

Being a older gamer, I remember when kids used to congregate at the mall arcade to see and play the latest and greatest in a blossoming video game industry. In this age of bleep blop beloop 8-bit graphics there sat in the corner the legacy of the last great gaming icons. The pinball machines. Like dinosaur bones they just looked really cool but no one would really play those when you had sitdown SpyHunter or Tron Discs to drop tokens on.
Yet I was attracted to these machines, whose art and design were always such a pleasure to see. And when games started rising to 2 tokens per play, the pinball machines stayed at one. So i started playing them, Black Knight, Fun House, Adams Family, etc.... and I gained an appreciation for the ancestor to my hobby.

Now all the arcades are dead. Im an old guy with a job i work too hard at. So when I found out about this recreation of the machines that were so cool to me back in the day, I immediately loved it. These painstakingly recreated pinball machines pull me right back into that mall arcade in 1986.

If youre a retro gamer, if you like pinball...you will appreciate this game.

8 out of 10.
