reviewText: Quick review to start: Holy cow is this ever fun to play!  The only caveat to recommending the Pinball Arcade is that, naturally, it's all about pinball and maybe that doesn't float your boat.  I do believe that pinball is universally entertaining however if you accept the inherent gameplay mechanics and so if you play this game you'll find happiness.\n\nThis is the second major pinball system on Steam now, but I will rate it unquestionably the best.  Why?  Because it *feels* perfect.  All the physics involved has a very satisfying sense of weight to it... the ball accelerates believably, the timing of when you strike the ball with your flippers affects the trajectory properly, and the rebounds from bumpers and sidewalls fits your expectations just *right*.  This is absolutely the best playing pinball experience you'll find on Steam.  There IS still room for improvement however but those are fiddly details that you'll hardly notice (the ball never leaves the table surface making certain actions reliably consistent compared with reality, the flippers are rock-solid and don't have any spongeyness" that happens with real tables
date: and the friction of the table surface and steel rails is constant which again makes the ball behavior suffer no random deviations).\n\nI've been familiar with pinball games
recommended: but I'm not a nut for the genre
hoursPlayed: and so I'm not bothered by the lack of absolute authenticity with the real tables.  Each game that's recreated here scores high by replicating a faithful experience.  You probably won't be able to "train" on these virtual recreations and expect perfect knowledge about how to work the real thing
voteText: but you WILL get all the entertainment that was built into the original games.  And on the note about those original games.... WOW!  The variety of tables to play is astonishing from truly old school pinball experiences from the 1960's to classic 70's and 80's table complete with early arcade sounds (I *love* those sounds!) to the zenith of pinball evolution in the mid 1990's.  The Pinball Arcade is truly a museum piece approach to the genre that shows no favorites for any one time period or manufacturer.  The breadth of choice is very
helpfulPercent:
very nice!

Some other things to note: all the tables present in this game are recreations of the originals which were designed to eat your money.  This is important to remember because even though there's no longer any quarters being spent to play there can be a lot of frustrating moments where your game ends prematurely because happenstance physics will cause your ball to drain no matter how skillful you can play.  It's possible to "nudge" the machine in multiple directions in an attempt to coax the ball into a different trajectory but I can't count how many times I've had terrible games because the ball just dumps itself down the drain prematurely.  Another important thing is that the game is going to be receiving a visual upgrade in 2014 when the developers release a DirectX 11 patch that adds much more modern lighting support and (hopefully!) texture map resolution bumps.  The game looks great already but these two additions will make the experience even more lifelike and exciting.

I do have some gripes to make about the game however.  Currently there's no support for Steam Friends in game
votesHelpful: which is something that Zen Studio's "Pinball FX 2" supports and I miss it.  You are encouraged to make a FarSight Studios account in order to have your scores ranked against other people
votesTotal: but there's something mighty satisfying about seeing your scores compared with people you actually know on Steam
votesFunny: and that's just not present right now.  Another complaint is that the Steam release still shows heavy connections to the Pinball Arcade releases on lower performance hardware (tablets
commentsCount: iphone
column16: Android
column17: etc.).  The game still PLAYS fantastic
column18: but there's a level of spit and polish to the user interface and camera controls that's just not right for a PC game and cheapens the experience.\n\nThe last thing I have to say about the base Pinball Arcade experience concerns the Free-to-Play nature of the title.  "Free-to-Play"... eh.... it is and it isn't.  When you download the game from Steam you will be downloading ALL the tables which you can play as long as you want UP UNTIL THE FIRST HIGH SCORE.  This is actually rather generous because it means there's no time's-up-and-you're-locked-out-until-you-buy penalty
column19: and in practice I found that the minimum high score threshold is high enough for you to play for a good amount of time in a single game and it's only when you really start getting your skill up that you find yourself hitting that ceiling.  Once you do starting bumping up to that limit you'll likely have found some favorite tables to play and you can then purchase them individually or all at once via the Season Packs.  There's even one pinball machine you can play forever (Tales of the Arabian Nights) that is extremely fun and definitely not a "throwaway bone" for the FTP monicker.\n\nFor all that this offers for free I say check it out right away and see if it finds a place in your heart... there's a lot to love here and I daresay if you're not a pinball fan when you start playing you will be when you're finished."

reviewText:
There have been a ton of awesome pinball tables over the years and Pinball Arcade is one of the best programs to come along so far to deliver the experience of digital pinball with actual table designs from years gone by. Granted, if you're not into pinball, there's nothing really here for you, but without spending any money you do get full access to one table and can demo every other table without paying a dime.

PROS: Very good (though not perfect) physics, table designs are nearly spot-on to the real machines, includes a mix of various tables from the most popular to the least popular, as well as from the most common to the absurdly rare, actual ROM data is being used so the tables have all of their hidden features and everything, all of which are documented in-game, extensive instructions available for every table to make learning the rulesets much easier.

CONS: Default configuration and camera settings are garbage for anyone looking to REALLY play the game, so you need to reconfigure everything, the Call Attendant" feature for dealing with issues can't handle most of the problems which crop up (which are thankfully few and far between)
date: very expensive if you want "pro" access to all the tables (extra configuration settings and options for examining the table)... still cheaper than owning just a single REAL machine. :P"

reviewText:
Changing my review from a tepid buy, to a buyer beware.

The trials are likely sucker versions, made to be easier, and I believe, more fun.
I did not opt to buy the pro/cheat versions.

At some point pinball tables were composed in such a way as to max,  profitability, at the expense of
a fun gaming experience.  Unfortunately,  PAs efforts reflect this concept perfectly.

PA tables are very pretty, nostalgic, but with only very few notable exceptions,  just not much fun.

Those wanting games for just plain fun, would do better to look elsewhere.  And do beware
when you see way too many positive posts, with practically no negative reviews.  More than likely shills.  This means a flood by promoters, rather than honest attempts to supply objectivity, and balance.   Happens online all the time.  Don't be a sucker.

Looks awesome, can't deny it. So I said let's give it a go, it's for free!

reviewText:
Those afflicted with tunnel vision and colorblindness beware!

Are you used to games where things are easy to see? Games like TF2, where the graphics are clean and the characters pop from 20 miles away? Then this isn't the game for you. This is a 12-inch-tall computer screen, not a 4-foot long board. Give us some visibility options.

reviewText:
If you are looking for free pinball, this probably isn't the game for you. If you are a legitimate pinball enthusiast, this game is well worth purchasing.

Though table packs are rather pricey, the amount of fun and satisfaction you can get out of one (Especially the first two seasons) are well worth it. Unlike Pinball FX 2 it's major competitor, tables in Pinball Arcade are LEGITIMATE real life tables that you know, love, loathe and remember.

Classics like FunHouse, Creature from the Black Lagoon, Star Trek TNG and Terminator 2 are all masterfully restored with realistic physics, all the legitimate features, bells and whistles of the original table. Marvellously simulated, these classic tables come with custom ball capability (Whether for visibility or just for shiggles), multiplayer options and a plethora of views to suit your taste.

The goals are realistically achievable and if you fancy yourself a wizard you can post your scores online to try to out-flip the rest of the cyberverse.

Lots of pros, with the 2 cons being A) price as the content rarely goes on sale and B) the lack of cross-platform account sync. (IE Though I have Season 2 Table Pack unlocked on my PC, I can't play those tables on my Android.)

Is this something you typical demanding ADD gamer case will want to splurge on? Probably not. But if you're a pinball enthusiast who has a hard time finding a place with solid tables to play or even who wants to practice for the real deal, you need to have Pinball Arcade (And ideally, seasons one or two table packs, if not both.)

reviewText:
There’s a nostalgic attraction to the concept of digital preservation - and the craft involved with an elaborate pinball table is an art. Leading the charge for commercial video pinball sim, Pinball Arcade seeks to emulate authentic tables as closely as possible.

A digital platform, the base package includes (depending on version) either 1 or 4 real life tables of historical note. New tables are added in packs of 2 as they’re recreated. Farsight has done a good job of mixing older tables with new; simple but groundbreaking boards such as Black Hole are represented along with relatively modern bombastic crowd pleasers such as Medieval Madness.

A strong aspect of the package is well-explained rule sheets with visual aids. If you thought pinball was sheer randomness, and never knew most tables have an intricate sequence of modes to activate for huge jackpots, Farsight’s respect for the game is contagious.

The only downside is a fundamentals-first ethic, leaving the presentation with the look of a cheap iOS game even in the console versions. Farsight intends to update the front end, but it’s a drag compared to the virtual arcade hangouts in the developer’s earlier generation Pinball Hall of Fame collections. Still, the play is what matters here. When at the table it’s the next best thing to owning a real machine.

reviewText:
amazing game.


this is very cool, challenging, addictive, both a vintage nostalgic, yet modern gaming experience, makes me want to track down and play an old pinball machine, fairly slim chance of that ever happening due to obvious reasons, this is the next best thing i would assume.

never played much actual pinball back in the day, the video arcade machines had taken over by the time i was goin to arcades as a kid, and the few I did come across never seemed to work, or always had some problems.

The vibrant lights, colors, sounds, everything, of all the old tables,  is perfectly captured, this is like a pinball simulator and with the old classic tables i assume alot of people have a favorite table, so each ones popular for its own reasons...the fact you can look at the vintage flyer ad of the original machine is very cool aswell.

and i only played the first free table, cant wait to try some other ones, lovin this pinball stuff lol.

I only wish the game let us examine the tables in more detail -- maybe a way to walk around the table and inspect every little detail on it.

reviewText:
Personally, one of the greatest FPS shooters of all time. I mean, really, you got the next gen graphics of a SEGA Dreamcast, all puckered up in the nice package of a Nalgene Hiker's Cantene. (Made in the US of A version, of course.) Now look hun, you may be saying right now, Patroklos, what does a Tabuu designed wallet from Six Flags have to do with the greatest 3rd Person Shooter in Bumble Bee Blast's history? Well I'll tell yah. Personally, I preffered the original Sonic the Hedgehog over Generations or Ep. 4, but in the end, you know, they all dah same. Now look here, tight skirtz on alligators may be rockin' thecaboose, but the only viable class in this game is the SMG genre. Trying to pull some S4 plays with CQC tactics just ain't gonna work no more. You'll get smoked, yah damned grease monkey. So, the conclusion: Flamingo kills ARE different than Dunder kills.

P.S.      If I knew Bubsy Adventure 3D and Dyrone Tonk were makin' an album, I never woulda hooked up with Hip Hop McGee. Please forgive me.

~The Culling~

reviewText: Not only am I huge fan of hit arcade games from the 90's but I'm also a huge one of Pinball machines. I give this game a very nostalgic score of S+

reviewText:
First off: This is the best Pinball Simulation ever! Non of the competing pinball games of the recent years even come close to the overall presentation and feeling of Pinball arcade.

Every table in this game is an extremely detailed digital replica of a realworld table. Everything is faithfully simulated, every light, sound and even the backboards. Nice touch: Every table comes with a little bit of trivia, where you can learn about it's original creators and history.

The pinball machines are sold separately or in season packs. Buying a season pass saves you a good amount of money over buying the tables separately. The amount and variety of tables in every season is spot on. OK, some tables are not my cup of tea, but the majority is very interesting and I love playing them.

There is just one little thing that I don't like about this game: The developers want extra cash for a so called pro" version of their tables. The difference is that you are able to access the operators menu that every table has
date: where you are able to change the amount of balls or at what score you get an extra ball. It seems a bit greedy to me
recommended:
that I would have to pay extra for something like that.

For an arcade freak like me this game is just great and highly recommended.
My verdict: 9/10 - Great game."

reviewText:
I absolutely recommend this game.  As a 20 year veteren as a Arcade/Pinball technician, I love that FarSight is making real world tables to bring back the memories from when Pinball Arcades were in their hayday.

FarSight is getting very comfortable in this niche and each table brings more nostalgia and excitement with each release.

The one thing that keeps me from liking Zen Studios tables more is that there nudging is not as fluent and realistic as it is in The Pinball Arcade. You get like 2 nudges per 15 seconds and then instant tilt no matter what.  Also, straight down the middle shot in Pinball FX 2 can not be diverted like you can in FarSights Pinball Arcade.   I enjoy PA tables so much that when they start supporting Xbox One (which they stated they will), I'll buy the tables all over again.

Here's to more happy pinballing in the future.  Message me if you have questions or want to add me! ^_^

reviewText: While this was already a wonderful game in DX9 mode, with the recent addition of DX11 support (if you have a recent and fairly powerful graphics card, I'm using two nVidia GTX Titan in SLI with 3D surround enabled here) this game now looks utterly stunning. I couldn't quite believe it was the same game, all of the tables look so much better, especially Black Hole, Attack From Mars, and Circus Voltaire. You can even adjust the room lighting (to around 20%) so as to give the feeling of a real arcade, and adjust the lamp brightness accordingly (55% or lower seems good). When playing with the nVidia 3D surround turned on (press Ctrl T to disable/enable it), there is still a little issue with the light from some of the brighter bulbs appearing to be rendered at a slightly incorrect perspective, i.e. floating" above the table. I'll try to bring this bug to Farsight's attention
date: to see if they can get it fixed
recommended: but in the meantime just lowering the bulb brightness slightly to around 45% when playing in 3D surround mode with DX11 seems to be sufficient.  Note: the room and bulb settings are under each table's options menu

reviewText:
It's an Excellent Collection of Pinball Games from the Video Arcade in which we all grew up with since we were children during the 1960s to Early 2000s.

The Tables Include:
Central Park = 1966
Big Shot = 1973
Gorgar/Genie = 1979
Black Knight/Firepower/Flight 2000/Xenon = 1980
Black Hole/Centaur = 1981
Haunted House = 1982
Going Nuts = 1983 (Unreleased)
Space Shuttle/El Dorado: City of Gold = 1984
PINBOT/High Speed = 1986
Victory/F-14 Tomcat = 1987
Taxi/Cyclone = 1988

Elvira & the Party Monsters/Black Knight 2000/Lights Camera Action!/Earthshaker! = 1989

FunHouse/Dr. Dude & His Excellent Ray/Whirlwind/Diner/Phantom of the Opera = 1990

The Machine: Bride of PinBot/Terminator 2: Judgment Day/Class of 1812/Party Zone = 1991 (You'll Be Back)

The Creature from the Black Lagoon/Cue Ball Wizard/Fish Tales/Black Rose/The Addams Family/The Getaway: High Speed 2 = 1992

Twilight Zone/Star Trek: The Next Generation/White Water/Tee'd Off/Dracula = 1993

The Addams Family Special Collector's Gold Edition/Red & Ted's Road Show = 1994

Attack from Mars/Theater of Magic/WHO Dunnit/JackBot = 1995

Tales of the Arabian Nights/Scared Stiff/Junkyard/Safecracker = 1996

Medieval Madness/Cirqus Voltaire/No Good Gofers/Starship Troopers = 1997

Monster Bash/Cactus Canyon/The Champion Pub = 1998
Harley-Davidson, 3rd Edition = 1999
High Roller Casino = 2001
Ripley's Believe It or Not! = 2004

reviewText: Nothing beats actually putting your hands on a pinball table and the feedback of pushing those buttons that send a little steel ball across the play field. reviewText:
I'm an old school pinballer who's had a bias against computer versions for more than 20 years. But Pinball Arcade turned me around with Theatre Of Magic. It was a table I loved, loved, loved back in the 90s. The IRL version, however, was notorious for breaking. We had three TOM's in my hometown (Athens GA) and at least two always had broken Trunks, which if you know TOM then you know a broken Trunk makes the game unplayable.

It took a second to get used to using the triggers on my controller, but once I did it was almost just-like the real thing.

The game, all together, is a little pricey but there's plenty of value for the money.

reviewText: The free table on Pinball Arcade (Tales of the Arabian Nights) is a meticulous recreation of an awesome pinball machine I remember playing when I was younger. In Pinball FX2 every table is new and the creators often chose to do things that work in a computer game but could never fly in an actual physical machine. The design here has a different feel. When the ball bounces off a bumper it seems more real and not like a digital object with a metallic texture.\n\nIf the tables were priced a little lower I'd snap a bunch up. Eventually I'll probably get one of the packs of tables, but the cost is a bit more than I would spend in an impulse buy, which is how I make most of my Steam purchases. But certainly the free table here is a lot of fun, so there's no reason to miss out.

reviewText:
I've turned around on this one. At first, I didn't care much for the old school approach. It isn't REALLY accurate. If it were, I could smack and kick the table.....and lose ridiculous amounts of quarters just to get my name on the top score. (I don;'t think that will be happening on this.)
I've found a few tables I played back in the day. That's what won me over....nostalgia.
Having said that, Pinball FX2 is modern and faster and fits the times. This one is NOT real pinball. It's a simulation of real pinball. There are things in REAL pinball that you can do with hand /eye/body cooridantion that you can't do here.
What do I mean by body? When paying real pinball,you can move, angle , shake the table, nudge lightly or hard. That's impossible to duplicate . So, to me, having been a real arcade-troll who actually played Elvira's table, and the Black Hole table, anyone who says this is real ...hasn't played real pinball.
Why do I like PinballFX2 better? It could be nothing more than the modern feel and the graphics. The gameplay is fairly similar....although Pinball Arcade doesn't alllow for a small space between lower flippers, which is accurate, FX2 makes up for it in speed and the need to be extremely accurate . It also employs video game animations and character models.

Does that mean I don't like this game? Nah. It's fine I just think the argument that it's REAL and FX2 isn't is absurd.

The other thing is, Pinball FX offers up better graphics out of the box....no need to have any special video card bs....or knowledge of how to change your video settings so you can play. THAT'S effed up.  They need to fix that and lower the prices. They want you to think they've done something special. They didn't even design the tables if you think about it. So....why pay more? I don't know. Seems like nothing more than el;itism and greed to me.

reviewText:
This review covers Black Hole, Ripley's Believe It or Not, Tales of the Arabian Nights and Theatre of Magic. I will edit the review if and when I buy and play more tables.

The pinball physics engine is really good for the most part. There are some noticeable ball speed issues where they seem to move at unrealistically fast speeds in comparison to real-life pinball machines. Depending on the table, there are some major differences between the quality of the textures and sounds, but it's usually acceptable. The worst textures are of the flooring and walls, but those can't really be considered as being parts of the tables. It would be nice if the developers actually made an effort to polish every facet of the game though, since the flooring and walls are also part of the gaming experience. At the time of this writing we are waiting on an apparently big DirectX 11 patch, but there's no telling if the overall look and presentation will actually be improved or if more negative aspects will be erroneously added because of the update. Let's hope it's a positive change.

Some tables seem to be plagued by various bugs. I'm not sure if these bugs are also present in the real-life machines, but in Ripley's Believe It or Not, there are some game breaking bugs. Balls will get stuck and the game engine doesn't recognize some key moments, and these bugs will make you stuck. The only way to fix it is to quit the game and go back. I've contacted support about these bugs and they said that they are aware of these bugs and are working on fixes at the time of this writing.

All four tables I played seem to be emulated well, despite the issues I've mentioned earlier. What's great about Pinball Arcade is that all tables available are based on actual real-life machines. You won't find any digital pinball related gimmicks or gameplay mechanics. This game is almost like an unlimited, interactive museum of these classic gaming machines where physics, reflexes, and skills are all that matter. On the other hand, in addition to the lack of overall polish and some bugs, my other complaint is about their pricing model. I understand some people may feel that $30 per pack is reasonable, but I feel that it's a mistake. If the prices were lower and if there were good sales, I'm sure they would sell much more on Steam. It also seems like the Steam/PC platform is not their priority, as they appear to be spending much more time with other platforms. Overall, if you have an interest in playing real-life pinball machines on your PC, this is probably one of the best options available, and new tables are supposed to be added on a monthly basis.

Pinball Arcade is good.

reviewText:
I wholeheartedly recommend this game to all-comers.

A whole caboodle of top-notch tables to pick from, wonderful physics, and a price that is fair given the quality of the reproductions and quantity of tables on offer.  I love the game so much I find it hard to find fault.

If I had to pick holes, there is the whole weird business of spending extra for the Pro setup which offers absolutely nothing of value whatsoever.  Also, not all the tables will be to your liking as they have a wide mix, and its unlikely all of them will be to your taste.

But really, this game is fantastic.  If you love Pinball, you're going to find this a treat.  And if you're new to Pinball, oh boy are you going to have a wonderful introduction ...

reviewText: If you've ever wanted to own real pinball machines but just didn't have the cash or the room for them then this is definately the one for you. It is nothing short of a work of art and nostalgia plays a big part. There really is something about playing on tables you have actually played in reality. Personally though I can take art or leave it. And in comparison with FX2 as a COMPUTER GAME Pinball Arcade is not going to please such a wide audience. The difference between the two is comparable to a top level flight sim and a  very good, playable, air-combat game. It depends exactly what you want. Some have complained about the price of the table packs and that it is listed as free". I disagree - there is a lot here for your money IF real tables are what you are after and the fact that you can try them all for free makes its claims perfectly valid. 89%"

reviewText:
القرآن)، ولا تتم الصلاة (وعبادات أخرى) في الإسلام إلا بإتقان بعض العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير من أهم الأعمال الدينية والفكرية اليهودية في العصور الوسطى. وأثّر انتشار الإسلام، وتأسيسه دولاً، في ارتفاع مكانة اللغة العربية، وأصبحت لغة السياسة والعلم والأدب لقرون طويلة في الأراضي التي حكمها المسلمون، وأثرت العربية تأثيراً مباشراً أو غير مباشر على كثير من اللغات الأخرى في العالم الإسلامي، كالتركية والفارسية والأمازيغية والكردية والأردوية والماليزية والإندونيسية والألبانية وبعض اللغات الإفريقية الأخرى مثل الهاوسا والسواحيلية والتجرية والأمهرية و الصومالية، وبعض اللغات الأوروبية وخاصةً المتوسطية كالإسبانية والبرتغالية والمالطية والصقلية، كما أنها تُدرَّس بشكل رسمي أو غير رسمي في الدول الإسلامية والدول الإفريقية المحاذية للوطن العربي.
العربية لغة رسمية في كل دول الوطن العربي إضافة إلى كونها لغة رسمية في تشاد وإريتريا وإسرائيل. وهي إحدى اللغات الرسمية الست في منظمة الأمم المتحدة، ويُحتفل باليوم العالمي للغة العربية في يسمبركذكراعتماد العربية بين لغات العمل في الأمم المد
واللغة العربية من أغزر اللغات من حيث المادة اللغوية، فعلى سبيل المثال يحوي معجم لسان العرب لابن منظور من القرن الثالث عشر أكثر من ألف مادة، بينما في اللغة الإنجليزية فإن قاموس صموئيل جونسون وهو من أوائل من وضع قاموساً إنجليزياً من القرن الثامن عشر يحتوي على ألف كلم
تحتوي العربية على حرفاً مكتوباً. ويرى بعض اللغويين أنه يجب إضافة حرف الهمزة إلى حروف العربية، ليصبح عدد الحرو تُكتب العربية من اليمين إلى اليسار - ومثلها اللغة الفارسية والعبرية وعلى عكس الكثير من اللغات العالمية - ومن أعلى الصفحة إلى أسفلها.
العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير

reviewText: The Pinball Arcade\nThe Pinball Arcade features exact recreations of the all-time greatest pinball tables from Williams®, Bally®, Stern®, and Gottlieb® together in one game. Every flipper, bumper, sound effect, and display pixel has been painstakingly emulated in astonishing detail! The Pinball Arcade is available for most game consoles, mobile phones, and tablet computers, including the iPhone, iPad, Android Phones and tablets, the Amazon Kindle Fire, as well as the PlayStation3, PS Vita, Xbox 360, and Macintosh.

reviewText:
I'm having fun playing The Twilight Zone on this table, but mainly because I have access to the real table and it's fun to see it on the computer.

Unfortunately there are a couple of fatal bugs in the game's feature Lost In The Zone" mode where afterward the game is unable to load the balls back into the "gumball machine" so the plunger is flooded with 3 balls at a time until you reset the table. It doesn't even recover on the next game without resetting the table. Another fatal mistake is that the multi-ball modes don't reliably auto-launch balls into play. Many of the balls that should be auto-launched are simply dropped to the manual plunger which is distracting and actually changes the gameplay.

Beyond the flaws in the table I've played the game suffers from extremely predictable physics. There is no randomness in how balls are released into play so it is very easy to predict where a ball will settle when introduced into the table.

I recommend this game to anyone who is looking to play a specific table that they know this simulator has available. If you simply want a fun pin ball experience there are better alternatives out there."

reviewText: Played this game to death on the Vita. I prefer authentic pins over fantasy-ish pins where lots of stuff appear on the table which can't be done on an actual pin (Sierra's 3D Ultra Pinball series, Pinball FX 2, etc), although I still play those pins sometimes.\n\nAside from the Pro Pinball series, TPA is one of the best pinball games I've ever played, especially when you consider all the tables were digitized from actual real tables. That brings me great joy, as I never once went to the arcades when I was younger and thus have never played any of these pins. I am happy there's at least one company out there willing to keep the legacy of pinball alive.

reviewText: Great idea to bring back the classic tables at a fairly reasonable per table price when purchased in season packs. Sadly this pinball simulator falls flat due to the lack of good camera angles. The only static top view is an unnaturally low angle to the glass making it difficult to accurate gauge the trajectory of the ball. It is sad that with so much effect put into the realistic simulation of the classics is crushed by such an easily fixed issue like camera angles. I am a big fan of pinball, but I am not a fan of this simulator.

reviewText:
The game is plain fun. Also, the devs are promising updated lighting and graphics going forward - so it will only get better.

Update after 50+ hours of playing:

I'm very happy there is a company digitalizing these classics and keep updating them. The new DX11 version of the game looks much better. Pinball is a lightshow - and now this feels like it too. Fingers crossed for better textures and higher poly models.

Also, I do hope they improve physics with even better ball on flipper interactions. They are so close to nailing the feel. All the real flipper tricks should be possible in game. Ball should hit the glass at times - like they do in Pro Pinball. Not sure if the ball jumps at all in pinball arcade? Surface interactions could use some improvements. Especially rubber.

Oh - redesign the menu please. It is horrible. Not that it matters a hole lot - but man. Just make a comfortable menu.
This is easy to add: a quick restart option.

I love this game because I love real pinball. Thank you and keep at it.

reviewText:
Can't recommend this at all. It's not free to play. It's a demo. The game has fairly good reproductions of a decent number of tables and if they were free to play on, things would be great... but they are not. I am told there's a new free table every month.... never found one. There's only one table I can find that you can play for free.

The rest of the tables have a score limit applied to them. exceed this score...and that's it, the game wants you to buy a table pack to continue. This would be ok if the score limit was set to a reasonably high level... but in every case, it's set so low that you don't even get a chance to determine whether the table would actually be one you'd be prepared to pay for. It takes almost as long to navigate the clonky menu system than the game itself will run for.

Essentially, think of this as a film. You're sat in the cinema, you're munching popcorn, there's been a few trailers, the lights dim, the words filmed in Panavision" appear on screen.... and then the film stops
date: the lights come up and someone immediately tries to sell you the film on blu-ray based on what you've seen so far... in the form of a box-set
recommended: bundled with some other films you've not had a chance to check out properly. These boxsets
hoursPlayed: they're not cheap either. I'd pay a couple of quid here and there for some of these tables
voteText: 20 odd quid though for just a few of the total available... no way.\n\nBasically then

reviewText: First, of course, as with any pinball simulation, don't expect perfection and don't expect it to outright replace real, physical pinball tables.  There's just no replacing the feel of a real pinball flying around a table with real targets, bumpers, and ramps, imperfections and all.\n\nOnce you get over that expectation, though, if you have any appreciation for classic pinball at all, you need to pick this up.  It's clear the developers have a deep appreciation for pinball, from the table effects to the challenges and detailed instructions so you can finally see just how each bonus worked on those tables you could never figure out.  Just because it can't be perfect doesn't mean it's not an outright fun nostalgia trip that's cheaper than actually buying and maintaining real pinball tables.
voteText: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've played this game a bit on Android and have been looking forward to a version on PC since the experience on a tablet is limited.

I think it looks good. Not great, but good. Sadly, they chose to use the same user interface, which I think isn't very good. Particularly not on a big computer screen. While the graphics are vibrant, there's something odd about the zooming/scaling causing jagged edges. I saw this on Android too. Anti-aliasing might help a bit, but still. Lastly, I wish they sold the tables as DLCs through Steam instead of in-game.

Anyway, this is the only proper pinball game on Steam at the moment. If you like pinball, you can't do much better.

I'd recommend checking out Pro Pinball too though, which have gotten a bit old, but are still very very good. They are also remaking them eventually.

reviewText:
OK, first some background information. I am not a hardcore pinball player, neither am I a casual one. I am somewhere in the middle.

At the time of writing this review, I own all the Season 1 tables. I also own all the tables by Zen Studious, a rival pinball company from FarSight.

To be honest, I enjoy playing pinball from Zen Studious than from FarSight on the PC. The reason being, the tables I played from FarSight just does not feel right. Mind you, in real life, I have never played these tables from FarSight on a table board before. The controls just does not seem to feel right.

However for all the Pinball enthusiasts out there, I would recommend this to them as well. There is no doubt that it was fun playing these tables from FarSight. For the casual players, I would recommend them to try the tables from Zen Studious.

So I would give this game a hesitant recommendation. If there is a button that says Neutral" on this review
date: I would most definitely click that."

reviewText:
Models, textures and lighting are Playstation 2 quality. Yes I said Playstation 2. Farsight made a set of these tables for the Playstation 2 for the Pinball Hall of Fame". They have since ported those same exact models and textures to PC and other platforms without a texture or model facelift. What you have is one of the ugliest modern day pinball simulators ever released in modern day.

The production values for this game are cheap and lazy. Farsight chose to make their new tables look exactly like their ported tables from the playstation 2 days in order to make everything look consistantly ugly.

This is not the way you treat classic pinball tables. These tables deserve to be remade digitally by a team of competent artists and programmers.

If you need to have your pinball fix. Buy zen pinball tables that are high quality or.. save your money and buy the real tables.  The digital recreations don't do justice to these classics."

reviewText:
--A Review By Penguincamp--

Well, I was planning to go to this Pinball Expo that was near my town, but it was cancelled for some reason. I was pretty upset about that, being a big pinball fan, and that put me right in the mood for this game, which I found just recently. I downloaded it and played it, and this is what I have to say about it.

First off, the remaking of each pinball machine is actually pretty impressive. I saw some of my favorites such as Taxi" "Funhouse" "Gorgar" and "Firepower" and they loooked pretty decent compared to their originals. The sounds from each pinball machine doesn't really have a difference compared to the originals as well. There's not a bad variety of pinball machines either

reviewText:
Wow, this game has seen ZERO improvements over the original iPad version I played years ago! The graphics are pretty bad (well, tablet quality really), but most importantly the ball physics are seriously off. Is this the best you can do, FarSight? You claim to be the ultimate accurate sim of real-life pinball machines and you can't get the physics down, after years of development? Take a look at the Pro Pinball series which still hasn't been matched in terms of ball physics. What we have here is about as accurate as a real pinball table covered with ice. I've owned and played actual pinball machines for a decade now and I can tell you that the ball should *not* go across the table at 45 degrees when I plunge it from the tip of the flipper. It should go *up*; not to the side! This makes aiming impossible if you're coming from real-life pinball. It's funny, the Future Pinball project had the exact same problem with ball physics. I wonder why...

Not to mention the poor and unrealistic sound effects used for the mechanics; these too seem awfully familiar from open source community attempts at pinball simulation from ages ago... you couldn't get a real machine and an audio tech to sample it for you?

I've been waiting for a properly simulated real-life pinball machine on PC for as long as I've played pinball, but it seems impossible to do right judging by this effort.

From an experienced pinball player in real life: not recommended.

reviewText:
Having played the Android version, I had high hopes for this game. I was not disappointed. The graphics are excellent, the physics are outstanding and there is Xbox 360 controller support so it get high marks on the playability fronts.

This is such a big thing that, except for original tables made by others, the standbys Visual Pinball/VPMAME and Future Pinball are no longer on my radar.

An excellent game indeed.

reviewText: Have a whole lot of love for classic video games and pinball machines and Pinball Arcade has rejuvenated those feelings in a major way. Have bought Seasons 1 and 2 on my Vita, Season 1 on Steam (will get to Season 2 when the budget allows), and have backed all 3 Kickstarter campaigns that have been run. Even though I own a Twilight Zone pin and can play it any time I want to go in the basement it is a blast to fire it up while I'm waiting on something to come through at my desk. Having played plenty on the machine itself I can't say enough good things about how accurately they've recreated the experience and feel digitally, plus everything simply looks beautiful. Between this and Pinball FX2 I'm actually now planning to slowly work on a digital pinball to play it all in style. Having toyed with the emulation scene versions in the past truly has made me appreciate the great work that has gone into this game. If you love pinball this is absolutely the best way to keep it alive and share it with a new generation.

reviewText:
Only one table is free. (Tales of Arabian Nights) The rest of the tables either have to be purchased as a season or in table packs. Otherwise the other tables have a score limit.

The only problem with this game is that the texture and lighting quality is quite bad, is the same as the playstation 2 pinball game released years ago called Pinball Hall of Fame". In fact this game is almost a port of Pinball Hall of Fame and not a brand new game. Despite many requests for improved textures and lighting Farsight has chosen not to address these issues. I am quite confused as to why farsight is releasing new tables with the quality of playstation 2 textures and lighting.

Although I own all four seasons for the Pinball Arcade. The developer ignoring small requests makes me wish I had simply kept money. For a better pinball experience with superior graphics and developer support I recommend zen pinball. reviewText:
I recommend this game with caution.  It's a very novel idea--it allows you to play numerous real life machines in about a 6/10 or 7/10 enviornment.  Why do I rate it so low?  The physics.  The good news is that we're far beyond the early 90s where multiballs just pass through other balls.  The bad news is if you want a 'real' experience, you'd be best to look at the Pro Pinball! series by Empire Interactive from many years ago.

Examples of differences between real pinball/this game:  Flippers don't have the same hydraulic movement that they do in real life--many tricks you can do because of the motion of the flipper are altered or not possible (drop catches for one).  The playfields have no dings / scratches / variable friction (Pro Pinball series actually simulates a 'worn in' machine to your liking) so the ball will travel in a pefectly consistent manner.  Flipper power is inconsistent--I've never seen a machine in my life that had flippers so powerful on Star Trek TNG.

There are very very few solid physics simulations on top of good gameplay for pinball machines.  It's basically the group that made monster's fair + the pro pinball series, followed by everyone else.  The pinball arcade belongs in the group of virtual pinball machines I'd definitely consider playing and are better than 75% of those out there, and loosely just as good as another 15%-20%.  It's not that 5% though and that's why I'd not recommend it.  Try it--make sure you're happy with what you're getting before shelling out the dosh.  It's enjoyable and can be a wicked fun night of nostalgia.

Don't get me wrong, Pinball Arcade is a good game. But I didn't like it for a multitude of reasons:

reviewText:
Over the decades I've been playing computer games I must have played (and completed) hundreds of games.

I can't recall ever having such a love/hate opinion of a game as I do for Pinball Arcade. I've changed my review several times for PA. At its best, Pinball Arcade is great. Tables like Fun House and Taxi are gems - well designed and fair tables.

Unfortunately the majority of the tables are very poorly designed. They aren't bad because the developers of PA did a bad job, PA does an accurate job, as far as I can tell, of recreating these tables. Unfortunately, these badly designed tables are designed to lighten your wallet by draining the ball with incredible frequency. That would be annoying in the arcade, on the computer it is annoying and pointless. Not that FarSight can do anything about this, they are doing their job in accurately recreating these tables.

I'm sure pinball experts will say that the problem is that I lack skill with pinball. I'm sure this is true, but a well designed game will give you an incentive to build your skill by rewarding you with higher scores. Having the ball drain through no fault of the player is not an incentive to continue playing, it is an incentive to move on to a better designed pinball table - a Pinball FX2 table.

reviewText: Just like with Pinball FX2, Pinball Arcade is worth a try since you can play one table for free and you can try out some of the other tables for a short amount of time. There is also the added bonus of free table of the month" where different tables are available to play in full when you select "play trial version".\n\nI played FX2 before I played this
date: so I will probably go into some comparisons with that
recommended:
so this review might be more helpful for those who have played that one are are wondering if this game is also worth it. I'll start out with the pros:

Pros:
-Well done recreations of real life pinball tables.
-Decent virtual pinball physics (but different feeling than FX2
voteText: tried and true classic tables to pick from. A few aren't so good but with how many tables there are you will still get your money's worth. I suggest buying them in the packs (and from what I've heard
helpfulPercent: people are having issues with in game purchases for the Steam version of this game
votesHelpful:
so you might be best off sticking to the packs).

Cons:
-Textures and lighting definitely need some improvement (improved lighting for the PS4 version
votesTotal: yet we're still left behind here on the PC).\n-Though physics are decent
votesFunny: ball can sometimes be a bit too fast and bouncy
commentsCount: sometimes making it all the way up ramps after a bounce that should barely have made it past the ramp entry.\n-Terrible UI. The menu system looks like it came from a half-broken game from the mid-90's
column16:
and it doesn't feel very responsive. Tables are selected from one long list and can't be sorted in any way.
-The extra features you get for the "pro versions" of the tables are not worth the extra price. I don't see why anyone should have to pay extra just to have access to the operator menu and a few other minor bells and whistles.

Now
column17: a bit more on the physics and the feel of the game. I did a short review for Pinball FX2 a while ago and was perhaps a bit over-zealous calling the physics spot-on. The physics in both these games feel very good
column18: the best I've ever felt in a pinball videogame
column19: but they are both a bit different and reality actually falls right in the middle of the two. If you are used to Pinball FX2 but have never played a real table
column20: I can describe the ball as being a bit "heavy" and it makes flipper catching and gaining control just a bit too easy. In Pinball Arcade
column21: the ball seems to feel a bit "light"
column22: sometimes traveling too fast and making some wierd bounces that send it up ramps and into places it normally would never go (yet despite the extra bouncing I almost never see "airballs"). It also makes flipping catching and gaining control a bit more difficult.\n\nIf you've never played on a real pinball table (or have only played a few times and it was a long time ago or something similar) then this probably won't bother you. However
column23: if you have at least some experience on any of the real life tables in Pinball Arcade then this can become frustrating at times. Balls will bounce into outlanes more than usual and sometimes you'll be struggling to pull off flipper catches that you know you can repeat over and over again in reality. However
column24: this extra difficulty is balanced a bit in the scoring by the fact that the ball might also bounce into places or make it up ramps that might not actually happen in reality.\n\nOverall I would recommend this game. It's a solid pinball title that does a decent job recreating real life tables. Just don't expect it to be perfect."

reviewText: This is by far the best pinball simulator I've ever used, and I've been playing them since the DOS days (I've also owned 2 physical pinball tabes). Great physics, impeccable graphics, and the loving design captures all the charm of the original tables. You also get a few paragraphs of history about each table and their popularity and historical relevance. There's nothing trickier than recreating mechanical devices on a computer and Pinball Arcade absolutely excels at this.\n\nAn unequivacally good game whether or not you've played the original tables. This is history come to life.

reviewText: Before I say anything nice, I have to voice that I am VERY irritated with the people who make this.  I bought it a year or two, back on XBOX 360, and every table pack they released.. the problem is, they only released 3 or 4, then stopped.. while the content kept coming on the PSN store.  I don't care why, but it REALLY sucks I had to pay for stuff twice, just to be able to get an up-to-date version.  That being said, if you have never bought this before, it is REALLY good (I own every table released by Zen Pinball on XBOX, but I really like how these are authentic tables.. ones I actually played growing up).  Zen Pinball has the edge as far as overall performance and presentation, but this is not far off at all.  Despite my jaded perspective towards feeling like the developer's screwed me, I HIGHLY recommend this.  At least get it for free while you can still get a free table (and a pretty decent one from the pick) and see for yourselves.

reviewText: As far as pinball sims on the market, or even pinball games in general, there has never been a more accurate representation of playing pinball in real life than The Pinball Arcade. It's the closest you'll get to real life pinball, and with a great selection of tables (with more coming out all the time), you're sure to find something you remember from your childhood within. Farsight's had their fair share of bumps on the road, but they've made up for it with heart and their pure love of the game. Tales of the Arabian Nights is free, so unless you hate fun, I can't suggest this game any higher.

reviewText:
This game is a dream come true. I absolutely love the Star Trek: The Next Generation table, playing it whenever I could in high school, so the Season One table pack was a must buy for me.
As someone who can't afford a real table yet, these collections of famous and historical tables is an incredible value. Plus, they take up MUCH less space in the house!

Edit: After playing for a while longer, I wanted to update my review with a caveat. I still love the game, and find it a beautiful recreation of the physical tables...but...it is occaisinally buggy, and the dev team doesn't seem to deploy fixes very often. I have only run into one game breaking bug on one table (Funhouse), but other, smaller bugs which have been identified by the community, remain in the game (looking at you, Arabian Nights top skill shot).

The tables are expensive and don't seem to go on sale very often. If you like pinball, however, and can put up with a few bugs and long times for patches, then it's worth an install - at least for the free table.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I remember playing Pinball machines as a kid. My cousin even had Big guns in my uncle's home, before it was moved out of the house for reasons i don't know. then i went to see my other uncle that i don't remember anymore before we head home. but before that, we stopped at one more RV camping site where there was Stargate the 1994 pinball machine, another pinball machine i don't remember what it was, and a few arcade machines. i also remember playing williams pinball classics on the PC and i don't know where it is now. but what i do remember were the tables i played. Arabian Nights, Black Rose, Creature from the Black Lagoon, and Lost World, i believe? Three of which were not by Willaims at all, but by Bally As i figured out recently. But playing Pinball Arcade as a Free to play Title, all the memories of my childhood playing pinball comes back, but with more tables i never played but intrested with they're own features. My favorite was Cirqus Voltaire for its creative designs, gameplay, and so on. As a Run in the middle pinball Apprentice, i was getting my on a few steam wallets to redeem them and buy a few tables for my pleasure and to see how much fun i had. for hardcore Pinball Wizards, i'd recommand it that much. Give it a try, can't be that bad. The tables perfectly interpretate the designs of the original physical models, digitized into our computers for us to enjoy.

reviewText: Pinball Arcade does an amazing job of replicating an authentic arcade experience. The physics feel realistic and the tables are lushly recreated replicas of physical pinball machines. The game features a good mix of popular tables, lesser known machines, and classics that're likely older than you are. Unfortunately, pricing is an issue; the game is 'free' with only one table, and limited demos of all other tables, and tables are only sold in packs of two and 'season' sets of all the tables released in a certain timeframe. These season sets are also at set prices, even as they place less tables in later seasons.  If there's only a couple of tables you want to play, they're likely bundled with another table you may or may not want, or you may pay for a whole season set, or get the 'pro' edition, which allows you to play with the physics and for certain licensed tables lets you scan the playfield to see the art, which is frustrating as it's not an intrisic feature included in all tables so you can see the work that was put into recreating these machines. Regardless, it's fun pick-up-and-play game, and it can help you learn-and play- the history of video games. Try your favorite table or wait for a season / pro set to go on sale. Recommended tables from Season One (only season I have) include Big Shot, Creature From The Black Lagoon In 3-D, Taxi, and Theater of Magic.
